posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9491586
Try Haste. It has the mappers from both wads (+Nirvana and Ribbiks). Most maps are shorter like in Micro Slaughter, but there are few longer that would fit right into Sunder or Abandon.

Also Bemused from Abandon made 6 map slaughter set Occula with Tourniquet few months ago. It's very fun.

There's also Fractured Worlds from last year. It has more Sunlust influence than Abandon, but it's one of best wads of the last year imo. Also has guest secret maps by Scotty and Insane_Gazebo.

Also Grain Of Salt releases his own slaughter/slaughter lite megawad Undo next March.

The Doomslayer in GMOTA is interesting because it's probably the first time a mod adresses the Sentinel from nuDoom and "expands" on them (because they barely had material at the time before Eternal)
Mostly because a lot of 2016 inspired mods are essentially "backporting" things that exist (even if not 100% faithfully) and GMOTA as a mod has a specific concept in mind, so the nuDoom/Slayer stuff (and the made up stuff for it) is a minor part
But between how limited Doom Eternal's modding is and some drawings people made of "original demon designs inspired by DE", i wonder if it'd take some "new Doom in old Doom" mod or Slayer's Testaments to "expand" the aesthetic/mechanisms of the new games
Like, imagine if someone did a small wad inspired by Urdak and made up a bunch of enemies based off the Maykrs, with a few based off actual concept art
And this is if a "classic take" on Urdak and Sentinel doesn't get creative, since the UAC/Hell are also portrayed differently in these new games
I remember Wad overdose on Doomworld doing "sprite" versions of someone's made up Eternal designs
I actually wonder about D3 having "original demons" too because stuff like the Arachnotron is based off official concept art and you had a PE and Baron that looked like modified Caco's and Barons
Pic related aged thanks to TAG2 but i also think the purple goo attack could suit a different demon design

Yeah especially with that purple sky. It can also help make some others realize how decently contrasted the game is, not just with lighting but hues as well.
Going from what >>9493248 mentioned regarding the palette, that’s something a lot of these devs were steering towards: Slightly to severely less saturated color palettes. You’re not likely to find a “blue” in the build trio that’s as vibrant as what you can find in Doom, Heretic, and Hexen.
>A bizarre yet beautiful stepping stone to full 3D.
Not really related to much, but I find the transition of Blood to Blood II morbidly fascinating: They went from having some of my favorite sprites out of any 90s shooter to one of the most unpleasant looking early 3D shooters I’ve seen.

posts.com:
https://www.mediafire.com/file/1djiv2hajqr56z0/Sonic+XG+Leaks.7z/file

If you don't know what XG is:

Sonic eXtended Genesis, aka Sonic XG, is a game being created by Sir Euan and Nitemare, and has gone through many different variations in the past.

At one point in time, the fangame was going to be merged with Retro Sonic in 2007 and eventually Sonic Nexus in 2010 in order to create Retro Sonic Nexus, but is again being developed as a separate title, with a new team of devs.

This is mostly all of XG. You have builds and source code from 2007-2021, and a level called "Golden Gate" from possibly 2005 to 2007.

Anyway, have fun with XG!

By the way, multiple people are leaking this. Saw one guy on YouTube. You can spread this around if you want.

The image attached is me inserting the Golden Gate level layout into the 2007 source code. It kinda worked, but I need to change the background.

I also leaked this in spite of the new devteam, which are kinda toxic and evil and shit.

So yeah, have fun.

>>9487829
What's interesting is how programmers can implement the rules of probability.
When is the outcome determined? When you initialise the screen? Or when you make the input to confirm your choice?

Using emulation rewind functions to investigate, In Wario Land's case it appears to be the former; the winning and losing choices are pre-determined (though I didn't ascertain if all three outcomes are determined from the start, or determined with each new opportunity, nor if "correct choices" are always the same on a per-level basis).

In this video, I quickly beat the first level, and coincidentally, all three winning choices were the left bucket.
The odds of that would be one in eight though. There are only eight possible outcomes:
>Left Left Left
>Left Left Right
>Left Right Left
>Right Left Left
>Left Right Right
>Right Left Right
>Right Right Left
>Right Right Right

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490387
Meanwhile, as an example of "determined at point of decision", are the Toad Houses from Super Mario Bros 3.
The contents of the chest are determined the instant you press the button to open it. The fact there are three chests is a total illusion of choice in this regard.

The contents vary depending on which Toad house you are visiting, but the first one in the game can only give you a Super Mushroom, Fire Flower, or Super Leaf.
Whilst all are beneficial, a "Super Mushroom" can be considered the least beneficial as it only gives you one extra hit compared to two extra hits (in the international release anyway), and doesn't give you a special ability.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490402
Also worth mentioning is the level up bonus in Super Mario RPG.
It also resembles a game of chance; will your picked bonus be higher than usual?
However, it follows an entirely deterministic pattern based on which level you just reached. This can be used strategically to maximise gains.

>>9490445
So in a matter of speaking, yeah it's when the choice to start the mini-game is made, as the time taken for the character to walk to the middle of the screen and begin accepting player input is fixed.

Also, the aforementioned 8 possible outcomes fits neatly into a 3-bit binary value, expressed as:
>000
>001
>010
>011
>100
>101
>110
>111

This is probably what the winning combination looks like in memory, meaning if you had a memory viewer running alongside the game and knew the correct address, you could see live which decisions to make.

>>9490387
you analysis falls flat.
you don't know when the PRNG is rolled.
it could be that the PRNG is updated at least once every frame. if this were the case, the outcome of the minigame depends on when you push the buttons, not what buttons you push.
there's lots of other ways the PRNG could have been implemented that would make any conclusions you draw from playing the game suspect. you really need to dive into the code.

a long time ago i used to think that the GB tetris piece selection algorithm tried to give you pieces that you "struggled" with more often. i would then spaz out I-pieces trying to game the system.
a few years ago i examined the assembly to see if i was right. in truth, the algorithm uses entropy from the noise channel in the sound subsystem to generate a candidate piece, and then tries rerolling 2 or 3 times if the piece was the same as the last.

>>9495215
If you have 100 or fewer coins when you start the minigame, and commit to the three rounds, these are your possible outcomes:
>Win, Win, Win - 800 coins (8x)
>Win, Win, Lose - 200 coins (2x)
>Win, Lose, Lose - 50 coins (0.5x)
>Lose, Lose, Lose - 12 coins (0.125x)
Note that the order of the wins or losses doesn't really matter, aside from when you halve an odd number and would lose a coin to rounding down (although if it rounds up, you would retain one more coin).

The potential gains are far higher than the potential losses, that losing three games is offset by a small win in one game.
If you set up a simulation to wager 100 coins from a pool, play three rounds and add the outcome to the pool, most of the time the pool will keep increasing providing your starting pool was large enough to weather early losses.

In Link to the Past, there is a treasure chest mini-game where you can pay 30 rupees to open two chests. I recall this is like the Toad houses where the contents are determined when the chest is opened.
I forget what the exact prize pool is, I'd have to look it up, but one of the prizes can be 100 rupees, so with each game played there is a chance to gain 70 or 100 rupees. Some of the other prizes include a smaller number of rupees, a bomb, a heart, I think an arrow, and of course a piece of heart which is the main incentive to play. Once you've received the piece of heart, that prize is removed from the pool and that increases the odds of receiving any other prize.

This mini game is a reliable source of rupees in the game due to the favourable odds, but it does rely on you having a good starting amount to weather the losses of early bad luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9495276
Actually, I found the prize pool, and this GameFAQs guide does a nice job of outlining the two other minigames I wanted to explain.
https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/snes/588436-the-legend-of-zelda-a-link-to-the-past/faqs/77032/mini-games

There are three chest mini-games:
>Verson 1 - Open 1 chest for 100 rupees
>Prize - 1 rupee (lose 99)
>Prize - 20 rupees (lose 80)
>Prize - 300 rupees (gain 200)
Your odds of gaining money is 1/3 and whilst the gain is great, the losses are harsh, and you're capped at carrying 999 rupees so this is generally not worth the risk involved.
Gaining 200 is very easily offset by losing 99 twice or 80 twice, and you can easily lose multiple times in a row. Statistically you would gain about 21 rupees every three games if you played lots of them, but the circumstances mean you'll play few and are more likely to lose out.

>Version 2 - Open 1 chest for 20 rupees
>Prize - 1 rupee (lose 19)
>Prize - 20 rupees (no change)
>Prize - 50 rupees (gain 30)
It's an even chance of winning, losing, or nothing happening, but the gains are greater than the losses, so statistically if you have the patience you should be able to keep gaining money indefinitely, but it will often be getting 11 rupees back as an offset for every 19 lost. That's not great.

>Version 3 - Open 2 chests for 30 rupees (you can get two of the same prize, Piece of Heart removed from pool)
>Prize - 1 rupee
>Prize - 50 rupees
>Prize - 100 rupees
>Prize - 1 bomb
>Prize - 1 arrow
>Prize - 10 arrows
>Prize - 1 heart
When playing this game you've got a 1/7 chance to gain 20 rupees or 70 rupees on the first chest.
This is trickier to figure out with all of the combinations available, but having two chances to gain at least 20 or 70 rupees per play by itself can make this a profitable game, offsetting the times you don't get any money out of it.

The SNES and the Genesis pulled about equal numbers in the North American market but that is with Sega shifting support from the Genesis to the Saturn in 94 giving the SNES 95 and 96 almost unopposed. From 91 when the Sega Genesis actually started selling in large volumes up until 94 Sega had a significant lead in the North American market. In Europe the situation was even worse for Nintendo and they never caught up at all even after Sega moved on. So often when a game was made in the west it was made with Genesis in mind and then ported to SNES. In Japan the Genesis was a footnote so in the rarer case when a game was made for both consoles it was usually SNES first and a port to Genesis to grab money from the western market.

posts.com: That Motorolla 68000 CPU in the Genesis/ Mega Drive was a big factor in it, because many of the 16bit micro computers like the Amiga, Atari ST and Macintosh all used 16/32bit variants of that CPU. EA was primarily a PC developer before they got into the home market with the Genesis. They avoided the NES because they didn't want to be locked into a Nintendo contract. They thought the hardware was old and outdated by 1990. They used their knowledge of the 68000 CPU to reverse engineer the Genesis and make their own dev kits, and used that as a bargaining ship to get a good third party deal with Sega. Which worked., A lot of developers who came from the Amiga and Atari ST were just really familiar with the Motorolla 68000 CPU. The founder of Travellers Tales Jon Burton was an Amiga demo-scener before breaking into the console market on the Mega Drive. Also the 68000 CPU was used in a lot of 16bit arcade machines. Really common CPU for the time. It's not like the SNES was hard to use in comparison, as it uses a 16bit variant on the 6502 CPU found in the NES. Apple used this CPU in their Apple IIGS system, and the Apple II GS was also used as a dev kit for the SNES. The SNES is really not a CPU driven system, and I think everything was mostly handled by the GPU instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464565
Prototyping ASICs. That's basically the reason they were invented.
Aviation and automation. It's cheaper in the long run to run the onboard software on an FPGA simulated ASIC than an actual ASIC because when some new bullshit law comes in that demands your component respond 0.0001% faster you can just update the hardware with new HDL at a routine service, rather than expensive downtime at a factory where somebody has to literally take it apart and solder a new chip on, and you don't have an expensive new ASIC run to produce.
Military. Same deal. Any hardware flaws can be fixed in the field, you don't have to say "sorry Vlad, can we postpone the war, we're upgrading our nukes to Ryzen."

>>9467459
>I'm still not sure what this thing is
You're familiar with the term FPGA, in a loose fashion, yeah? MiSTer is a project that is taking advantage of a cheap FPGA that people can buy, called the DE-10 Nano. The DE-10 Nano is cheap because it is made for college students, and is subsidized by Intel. The DE-10 Nano has an FGPA on board, as well as an ARM chip. It has various connectors on the board for expandability. MiSTer has a bunch of FPGA cores (much like the cores you would see on one of the Analog systems) for consoles, handhelds, arcade boards and computers. Developers are constantly adding more cores and improving on existing cores. A hobbiest community has popped up around this project, which has led to a lot of hardware addons that can be installed onto the DE-10 Nano, such as extra RAM, a digital or analog I/O board, USB hub (these things make up the most common MiSTer setup that you have likely seen, which is a sandwich of three boards with the DE-10 Nano in the middle)... etc. There are people who have made specialized expansion boards like the MiSTercade, which allows it to be used in a typical JAMMA arcade cabinet. At a base level, you really just need the DE-10 Nano, and preferably a RAM stick, the rest is optional.

MiSTer can be appealing to enthusiasts because it offers better accuracy/latency compared to software emulation. It's also very easy to set up and use in a variety of scenarios, without having to invest in a bunch of extra shit like flash carts, upscalers, custom cables... etc. It is an all-in-one solution for many of the systems that a retro gamer would be interested in. By its nature, it is also very customizable.

I still think that software emulation is a good option, especially on a budget since you can probably do it on hardware that you already own, however I do like my MiSTer quite a bit and I find that I am playing more /vr/ games than ever since getting it.

It's the perfect middle ground. You've got original hardware accurate latency, perfect audio timing, ease of use with a CRT and compatibility with a number of peripherals, tied with loading roms, save states for some cores, using any controller you want, and emulation perks like CPU overclocking for SNES.

If you're into collecting and playing carts, then go real hardware. But if you were just going to buy flash carts for all of your systems, I don't see any reason not to just go the mister route. You're getting the same console quality experience. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9472727
Everdrives are great if you want to play on dedicated consoles. Excellent if you already have real hardware and don't mind buying a unique everdrive for each console.

With MiSTer FPGA, you load all the ROMs for the supported console cores into one SD card and only have to deal with one set of hardware.

There is no best way, only options in which you weigh out the benefits for yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464069
Runahead latency isn't accurate. FPGA is latency accurate, in that a good core can reasonably achieve identical latency to original hardware.

Additionally the overhead to achieve accurate latency is much easier. Software emulators generally try for timing accuracy or cycle accuracy with a lot of optimization and tricks required to do so. With FPGA once you've defined the logic it mostly just works how you'd expect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464110
With FPGA the actual video circuit of the recreated system directly drives the raster of the CRT, just like the original hardware could. You will always have a framebuffer on PC, always some abstraction away from native interf
aces.

That looks like a cheap scaled-down version of Sanni's cart reader, you can build your own if you are handy with a soldering iron, or you can find some place that has the latest (version 5) pre-built.

https://github.com/sanni/cartreader/

The latest version (If you build the model with all 7 cartridge connectors) does NES, Famicom, SNES, Sega Master System, Sega Genesis, Sega CD RAM carts, N64, GB, GBC, and GBA.

There are adapters to also make it work with TG16, Wonderswan, Game Gear, Neo Geo Pocket, Intellivision, Colecovision, and a dozen or so other systems.

>>9477134
Japan has an inclination to do stories of the young because of initial post-WWII ideals. They were slower in growth and did not lend to people of that generation immediately creating new stories. It took Japan longer, like the first Godzilla struggled to get made because of anti-Japanese sentiment. It impacted them culturally and they didn't have a boom. By the time thedid rapidly expand, it was younger people making the stories, who had a different perception of WWII and Japan as a whole. since the 60's and 70's Japan has just very heavily leaned into using young people in media.

On the contrast to what the west was doing. The growth of hollywood never stopped during the war, only shifted. And the stream of stories was always on the middle aged. It wasn't till the 50's that the west also started incorporating young people into their stories.

I think FFX suffers from some slight issues, as far as intent and facts though. Auron is supposed to old at age 35 and even refers to himself as young 10 years ago, when he was 25. Yet we have a maester who has served for some 70 years. I think what happens is characters get designed and created and then put into a story and not organically written. So it's part of the overall media franchise machine.

Lulu's path is a unique one, as for most of the game lulu is your only nuker and you can get magic boost weapons for kimahri and he can help clean up enemies weak to that.

Wakka and Auron paths are fine, but don't offer that much, unless you just wanted to use Kimahri over those characters.

>>9490571

Yes.

Some GREAT fucking ST games. They are not all exclusives, but the ST versions often have their own charm:

Time Bandits https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VrvIgbsEG-A&list=PLD7CEB7FCED6C99EC&ab_channel=Chelseacf
Mudpies https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8u5uMS50qNc&ab_channel=Steve%5BAtariCrypt%5D
Sun Dog https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kg_hEY_hy9U&ab_channel=Wasabim
Major Motion https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bASGBe6jhes&ab_channel=Nival
Bratacas https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PRWzrKvqnKs&t=93s&ab_channel=W.D.Callahan
Hacker https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SHrLhk5StY&t=379s
Hacker 2 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mOgkET76VTE&t=244s

Those are just the ones I had growing up. There are a lot more. Learn the emulator and get the roms from the pirate disks:
https://www.atarilegend.com/menusets

These are all pirate disks, you'll want to look up what's on them online, or in this site. Basically, back in the day, pirates would crack and compress games and put them into a single floppy image so people could pass around pirated games. Like, it was physical piracy. The sort of stuff you kids love to hear about. The only reason we have the ST catalog anymore is because of these pirates. Automation, Pompey Pirates, Zuul and the others. Some of these disks have viruses on them, but like... who cares? Harmless, and kinda cute!

People do still use these things for MIDI. The beat timing is PERFECT. You can't really get that perfect timing with a machine that parses time by the femtosecond. Like, a new PC just doesn't have that PERFECT beat timing, say some musicians. We could all debate this, just like we could debate vinyl versus digital, tubes versus circuits, etc.... There's a guy in LA who owns all these things and sells them for parts and replacements into the industry. I sold him pallettes of the things in the early 2000s. Shoulda charged him more.

Have fun, explore. There's a lot out there.

>>9490571
Its biggest selling point was the MIDI interface that was used in studio and hollywood productions. Had LOTS of great homebrew/shareware/independently published software packages, game experiments, and utilities. Most games were pretty close to the Amiga ports but I unfortunately have to admit a lot of big titles often ran better on the Amiga. However it was an exceptionally soulful machine and I think the much larger catalog made it work.

I don't know if anyone else will remember this, but there was a company called BRE Software that put out a periodic catalog where you could order floppy disks and they had just TONS AND TONS of random weird shit you could get, tools, programming samples, demo scene shit, ports of unix roguelikes, BBS software, etc etc. It was so great, what a wonderful wild west time in software development. Sadly the company ended up just becoming a generic Xbox/Playstation store after the 16-bit computer market died out.

>>9491037
Time Bandit is one of my all time favorite games. I love the hybrid elements of run and gun gameplay with some of the areas having different level of story/puzzle elements embedded in, mixing pure action and text adventure depending on where you go. I really feel like modern takes on these elements could do very well.

Also the GFA Basic programming language on the ST was fantastic, very powerful and expressive.

the Mega Drive couldn't use an even 8Mhz either for the same reason, they had to clock it to 7.16Mhz so they could subdivide the 3.5Mhz NTSC burst. >>9491679
The original is a pretty good game in its own right.
Something to note is that the UE1 engine games (Unreal, Unreal Tournament (sequel) have some compatibility problems on modern systems. Patch both with their latest Old Unreal patches and this is my subjective opinion, but stick with the legacy Galaxy audio system for sound. The other audio systems have different quirks that affect how effects and music are mixed and propagated in the games and they don't feel quite right to people that have played them before, someone new might not care but still the right choice imo.

Also the games are supposed to have some neat looking volumetric fogsl effects, but sometimes the games automatically disable it because of outdated hardware checks. You'll have to read about how to force them back on in the advanced preferences menu of the engine if they get disabled.

Unreal Tournament has a full campaign ladder mode for solo play that takes you through pretty much all the game's content. UT:GOTY features a new Skaarj hybrid team and a revised campaign ladder with different maps, omitting an iconic map 'Barricade' that I actually kind of liked. There's a one line setting in an .ini file for switching the game back into its original 1999 state if you want. All maps can be found in the practice menu for custom matches.

UT2k4 has a slightly less developed campaign mode that only gives you a fraction of the total content. Use Instant Action to explore the full game.

Unreal 2 is mediocre, but it doesn't suck, imo.

What does it come with?

I think the best Unreal game is UT 99 by a hair. 2004 is also exceptional, and I could understand preferences either way. So on that alone I'd probably play 99 for 2k4 first depending on what looks better to you and then if you like one try the other one. Both have surprisingly competent singleplayer campaigns. UT99 still has a multiplayer scene but unless you are experienced in this type of game you'll probably spend most of your time eating shit.

Unreal and Unreal 2 are also very good games in their own right. The original Unreal is a bit of an odd FPS in that the pacing is really slow, but it's also absolutely brilliant visually and if you get into it the atmosphere is fantastic. It's fairly long, though, and if you don't like it in the first five hours you can safely drop it. It's definitely not for everyone.

I haven't played Unreal 2 since it launched, but I liked it quite a bit at that time. Come to think of it, that's basically the only thing I remember about it.


(So the racist Quake guy doesn't waste his time responding to my posts: Yes, Q3A is a better game than any of the Unreal Tournament games. I'd also say the original Quake is better than any UT. That doesn't change the fact that it's still a very strong series with multiple exceptional games.)

>>9487457
>Deja vu has absolutely no softlocks unless you count the glitch where you die three times in a row on the same screen and it erases your save file. They went out of their way to include failsafes.
I've actually found the softlocks in Deja Vu. I managed to run across all of them while playing the NES version as a kid. The mugger in the street and the thug in the alley are possible soft-locks. If you've already hit the mugger a few times, the next hit results in death. The only way past him after that, and the thug in the alley, is the $20 bill in your wallet(or one you steal from Sugar Shack after knocking her ass out). If you spend that $20 on a new gun to avoid another soft-lock, then you can wind up stuck with the mugger or thug with no way out.
Why buy a new gun? Because there is a random soft-lock in the sewers after you get rid of the murder weapon. I had it happen to me. After throwing away the gun, you can encounter the Alligator in the sewers. Only way to survive the gator is to shoot him. No new gun = stuck in the sewers with no way out other than death.
I actually recommend headed to the police station prior to going to the sewers just to encounter Sugar Shack, knock her out, and take her money to get yourself the new gun before going into the sewers, so you still have a $20 for the mugger, then staying out of the alley where the thug is. This way you avoid both potential soft-locks.
Another softlock happens if you enter a cab and travel but don't have the 3 coins to pay off, or leave Peoria St with less than 6 coins. Can't pay the cabbie with cash, so you get stuck.

It has some kind of specific state the game needs to be in in regards to certain flags before the case is considered "solved", and it's always a bit illogical in regards to what exactly the player needs to have specifically done. Adventure games have always had an issue with how the player character can pick up an item and hand it to some dude without actually having a reason for it, and it just feels dumber when you're playing a detective that shows up in court with a bunch of crap and presents it as "evidence" despite not actually having bothered to even look at it.

Silent hill 1: never played it

Silent hill 3: Honestly one of the weirdest games I have played, I found myself questioning the game more than anything. The horror aspect was just not there for me honestly. Puzzles are dank as always.

Silent hill homecoming: hilarious yet fun game, I believe this game mixed with silent hill 2 would have been a masterpiece. Would be hard to pull off though.

silent hill downpour: did not finish it, forgettable game.

You could say I have a bias since I broke my horror game hymen with RE4 then played dead space after that. I would even put dead Space 1&2 over the silent hill games. That is just me.

This is not discounting silent hill games since I would play silent hill 2 in a heartbeat. Other than that, it's not the goat for me.

My first couple horror games were: RE4, dead space 1&2, Condemed 2: Bloodshot

posts.com: it seems a faux pas to say, but i think RE4 really is the best horror game. it has a lot of action and 80s tier one-liners, but it's easy to forget about some of the legitimately creepy moments. as a kid, i always ran through the village at night when you first get ashley because of how scary it was; being in this pitch black, rainy farmland with a bunch of demented spaniards lurking in the dark is pretty unsettling. that's to say nothing of the first time you see regenerators, or even stranger shit like the bag in the dumpster that convulses. the way the game uses music to build atmosphere is fantastic too -- e.g., the merchant theme which is calm and protective but always serves as a warning of something sinister to come. the game's ability to create a sense of claustrophobia and dread is frankly amazing.

posts.com: I've been getting into this genre the past few months and one aspect of this genre that really surprised me was the realization of just how small it really was. There's a million RE games, a handful of SH games that actually matter, and then a lot of one off shit that either never caught on or was based on an some IP at the time. RE has definitely cemented itself as a pop culture icon, so why did the actual survival horror genre die so quickly exactly? By seventh gen it was all but dead, with only a mild resurgence in recent years. Perhaps it's part of an appeal to the genre but so many other games in this genre generally feel more along the lines of "passion projects" with a number of apparent flaws that would turn off average consumers, only RE and SH really feel like true "big budget" experiences. I was only born in 98 but to anyone that grew up with it just how long did RE stay relevant? It feels like RE2 was definitely still fresh in the minds of people but by RE3 it seems like there was a decline in interest overall.

This is a great question, and I'll try to answer it from my own point of view. Personally, I feel that the only games that have ever tried to imitate Resident Evil are its own series, and Dino Crisis 1. This is even debatable, as truthfully the only REAL survival horror games, as in games that both combine survival AND horror, without going down the more action heavy route, are RE1, REmake, and Dino Crisis.

Back to the subject though, you'll notice all of REs knock-offs barely ever tried to imitate its style. Even Silent Hill, its greatest rip-off, is absolutely nothing like Resident Evil. It has virtually no item management, and ammo is not scarce at all. Most of the games just try to rip off its camera angle and let you shoot monsters. But how many tried to copy the Mansion, or added in interesting, well-thought backtracking? How many are actually scarce on ammunition, or force you to really strategize how you go through each room? It just doesn't exist. I'm not sure if Resident Evil was just that good, or the developers were just flat out lazy and all of the clones were cash grabs. But they aren't very good in comparison, and they all lack polish.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9488479
I think SH3's strengths get overshadowed i general. It's a weird game in the series, it acts as a continuation of SH1's plot while telling a more personal narrative about Heather like SH2, making it feel "redundant" in ways. SH3 both tries to tell a deeper narrative happening around the protagonist and those around her but also have her experience her own personal journey, it's a very ambitious narrative that, overall, I would say works out well but doesn't feel quite as cohesive as the prior two entries. Generally I think people see SH3 as having "less meaning" in what the game, and this is true in a few regards but still pretty inaccurate to the overall. Honestly I think the symbolism and themes go over people's heads because they're so heavily based in the feminine experience. If you're a guy I feel like it's likely you just kind of don't think about things like the game's various menstrual imagery, though some things like the hole leading to the final boss are hard to miss.

I always have a hard time deciding between SH1 and SH3 as my personal favorite. SH3 has a lot going for it with the most refined gameplay and graphics of the series, but it's also the most obviously compromised of the first three games. The game has essentially no exploration outside of the dungeons and a handful of "grab thing, walk a room over, use thing" moments. It's a great game on its own merits, but how it compares to prior entries and their strengths gives a lot of differing thoughts. I would say that, as simply a "video game", that SH3 is the best, as to be expected being the newest, but it's clear pure gameplay is not why people love horror games.

That's the gameplay genre. "Horror" isn't a video game genre, it's a theme. As a video game, it's an action game, and it has a horror theme.

>because it's literally impossible to point to one specific thing about a game genre that should be reflected in all games of that genre.
You've tried to do that several times for survival horror. It can't be done for "horror" as a theme because that's not a game genre, but I've successfully defined survival horror that still has no rebuke.
> 'action' can mean all kinds of different things but its still a game genre
I like this definition: "An action game is a video game genre that emphasizes physical challenges, including hand–eye coordination and reaction-time. The genre includes a large variety of sub-genres, such as fighting games, beat 'em ups, shooter games, and platform games." Fits every game you'd want to describe as an action game, in terms of their gameplay focus. Normally you would say the sub-genre, but if you said "action game" then you know what the gameplay will revolve around: hand-eye coordination challenges. There are action games that are also horror. Not survival horror.
> notice how you again conceded the inventory management point.
You never finished your point or responded to mine. What does moving the items around do fundamentally to the gameplay? You aren't prevented from continuing the game if you don't move them around. The reason it's even mentioned as a thing in other RE games is because you have to make sure that you have space for key items, which requires sacrificing already limited space.
When I mentioned RE4 has unlimited inventory space for key items, you said it would be absurd to try to play the game otherwise. Why? Because then you'd have to balance your weapons and ammo with the key items. Crazy? For a game that emphasizes combat, not for a survival horror game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9494556
Emulation is fine, but make sure you can see the post processing effects otherwise you'll lose out on the panic "meter" (it's the whole screen), lighting, and reflections. Software mode works 100%, but I think one of the hardware modes works now if your computer can handle it. Use this timestamp in this video as a reference for what I'm describing.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ektkbejc-sE#t=11m37s

Notice how the screen turns more black&white, and slightly blurry when her heart beats, as Fiona inspects the blood? That's her panicking. The effect gets more pronounced the more she panics, until she loses it. It's important to the gameplay so you understand when you need to calm down.

posts.com: I always thought that the Master System gamepad sucked. I have used the variants with the screw in thumb stick and the ones without, and I just never liked the pad. I like the 3-button Genesis pads, they are fine. But lack of buttons in games can be an issue. Used the OG 6-button gamepad, I think it is one of my favorites. I have used both the US and Japanese Saturn pads. The US pad does feel more like the 3-button Genesis pad when you hold it. But I don;t think the buttons are bad. The L and R shoulder buttons felt a little finicky. own some Dreamcast pads, and while I don;t think the pad is as bad as people say it is. The face buttons are fine, the analogue stick feels good. The L and R triggers are a hard plastic and can dig into your fingers. The D-pad is good. Weird side step of the Saturn analog gamepad. In ways i think the Saturn NiGHTS pad is better. But Sega were definitely trying things with the DC pad.

The engine is actually very advanced for a 1993 game.
>perspective corrected textures
>3d audio positioning
>huge draw distances
>bsp trees based optimization to avoid drawing unnecessary stuff

Compare to something like Tomb Raider or Turok, where maps are made of very simplistic building blocks. Even with real 3D objects and over/under rooms, these two have more primitive maps and laughable draw distances.

This new black Trinitron has much better geometry than my WEGA, probably by virtue of having a rounded screen instead of the WEGA's flat glass, BUT the convergence issue you mention is all too real. Subtitles in games like Shenmue (where subtitles are difference colors, not just white/black) look really awful, but otherwise this new Trinitron is absolute king for 8-bit and 16-bit games. I forget just how good Hard Corps looks on a big tube.
I read up about how to go about fixing convergence though and it looks like there's three ways to go about it, depending on the gravity of the issue.
>Move the Horizontal alignment physical thingy inside the chassis.
>Move the Vertical alignment rings around the yoke itself.
>Stick more convergence strips inside the yoke, maybe even move magnets around.
In my case, the convergence is only really off on the borders of the image, so I only really need to play around with the "convergence strips", whatever that is. Will look into some home-made strips though, since I really doubt I'll be able to find these things on sale at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485672
>That's not how TVL works.
Stupid faggot, that's exactly how it works

TVL = Horizontal Resolution
SNES/Genesis after PAR adjustment = 292x224

Assuming no overscan you can display all detail with 292TVL and and anything more than that and it looks oversharpened.
But CRTs always have overscan so you can never get it perfect.

Example
Top
15 inch consumer CRT component

Bottom
500 line PVM 14 inch RGB

The lower TVL looks far far better
But even that isn't perfect since you have screen-door effect because of the dot pitch being bigger than the pixel pitch.
The only way to achieve perfection is near-neighbour scaling into 12000-20000 PPI displays which is still a long way off.

>>9488437
Oh hey good timing, you asked right as I was checking back on this thread
I had two wired Retrofighters Brawler64s that crapped out on me. Basically the analog stick started dropping inputs, so for example if you were running forward as Link in OoT he would stop and start - essentially unusable. Both had the exact same problem.
Unfortunately they both had fallen just outside the warranty window, and their support didn't even reply when I sent them like a "Hey, anything I can try to do to fix these?"
About a year later someone on twitter was asking about them, and I outlined that whole chain of events to them and said that I don't recommend them at all. From that tweet, their PR/customer support team reached out to me and ultimately actually shipped me two of the newer wireless versions by way of apology. And the wireless one has held up a lot better than the originals. At least, so far.
So maybe the takeaway is, they used to be utter crap, and now are (hopefully) a lot better. The analog stick on all of these these is just kind of weird though.

In the interim I used the wired Retro-Bit Tribute64 (which is modeled after the famous Hori N64 controller) and I actually liked this a lot better than any of the Brawler64s. The only problem with these is that the connector has an absolute death grip on the controller port, which is why I switched back to the wireless Brawler64 for right now - since I didn't want to be unplugging and replugging that controller all the time, and wireless controllers just keep things a bit more tidy. You know how it is.

There is an N64 controller purist on this board who will tell you that the analog stick sensitivity and deadzones of any of these 3rd party controllers is crap compared to the original - he's got charts and whatnot to back it up. He's probably right, but it's never really bothered me and or caused any real problems.

Of these I'd recommend the Tribute64 first.

>>9490051
>>9491313
Safest bet would be to open the thing and check all capacitors with an ESR calculator. Replace the bad ones with new capacitors of the same specifications and pray that it works.
When it comes to these old machines, capacitors are almost always the suspect number one because they tend to fail earlier and when they do fail (and they will), they bulge up and start leaking on the main board, so you want to take care of that as soon as humanly possible.
If you aren't one for soldering, you could ask someone to do it, but it's questionable whether professionals will work on CRTs nowadays. Definitely a good skill to have though or, in my case, know someone who does that kind of thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9492425
that's pretty tough to answer
generally with gen 7 imo you want to be on a modern TV because all of gen 7 supported 480p (and beyond), and your CRT will likely only support 480i
So while gen 7 consoles can output a 480i signal that works on consumer CRTs, the software was pretty much all designed for 480p (or 720p, in the case of most PS3 games afaik). So right out of the gate on a PS3, you're taking a huge quality loss when using a CRT just because of the signals it can handle.

Pretty much all of the "Wow, this looks way better than my old CRT!" talk comes from back in the day when people were viewing a 480i signal on their CRT and then switched to a 480p signal on their flatscreen during gen 7. And I don't really think there are any games where you'd be like, "Now THIS. THIS game was MADE for a CRT!!", that's all up to personal taste.

I dont know why you dont get this, but 540p is progressive 1080i
If a TV supports 1080i natively it supports 540p.
Pretty much nothing uses 540p, but it is still lagless and you can input it with a PC via VGA or even component with a transcoder.
https://www.avsforum.com/threads/do-crts-have-a-native-resolution.556870/
Majority of HDCRTS sale 720p to 1080i
Another example of a Sony:
https://shmups.system11.org/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=68605
Some expensive HDCRTs do support 480p and 720p because they are cummonly used, but it requires some multiscanning capabilities in the TV and non multiscan crts scale 720p and 480p.

No that long ago I was playing Xbox 360 games at like 10fps, but that's a whole other matter.

Those elementary guesses are about all you get though. Compare the forest temple to the big house in the sky from SM64. There's ultimately nothing to the Mario house. You can write all the fanfictions you want about who the owner is and why they live in the sky, but ultimately the game doesn't supply you with anything.

The forest template obviously has a bit more character than the Mario house, but they ultimately have the same purpose: a big building with a mcguffin inside. No NPCs will tell you anything about who used to live there. Neither of them have so much as a bedroom or a kitchen. It's not a big deal for Super Mario, which cares famously little about plot, but OoT really does try to flesh out its world, so I wish it had given the temples more substance.

>>9490640
This. The logical conclusion is to get the correct controller for each of the consoles you plan to emulate. Because of the gulf in quality between first party controllers and third party USB clones, you're going to want first party original controllers and of course because there is no way to connect them to a PC, high quality adapters for them so for every emulator you'll have to drop around $25-50 + $25-45 for controllers and adapters. Before you know it you'll be knee deep in a bin full of controllers with different dongles. Hope you got high quality ones, chink ones don't even last 5 cycles.

So the cost of free emulation after a $1000 + PC is pretty high. That's about $80 for each console you want to emulate. Now you just have to spend time configuring every game for every emulator, setting up hacks so they actually run, pining for fixes in nightly releases and tweaking CRT shaders.

Will it be worth it?

>>9490375
I know the answer to this. It's objectively the PS3 controller and I'll tell you why. Xbox controllers don't have the gyroscope or whatever it's called (six axis motion?) and the PS4 controller comes close, but it doesn't have pressure sensitive face buttons. Most controllers have pressure sensitive triggers, but that's it. Basically, this is the only controller that allows you to lightly press any button and also registers tilt. Why does this matter you ask? Because there are a few games where this is absolutely needed. If I remember correctly, the Metal Gear solid games from the ps2 needed this and when they were ported to xbox they needed to redo these mechanics. Also you can emulate the ps3 nowdays so there's Heavely Sword, etc. The only downside is that it doesn't use a micro usb like the PS4 controller, it uses a mini usb. But get the cable and you're set.
>ps3controller.jpg

posts.com:
There's a fantastic PE artbook on archive.org.
https://archive.org/details/ParasiteEveNewType
It has storyboards for all the CGI sequences and, since they were made by Square's American office, all the notes are in English. I had to downsize and compress this to meet the filesize limits, but they're easily legible in the actual scans. There's some neat content that got cut in a few of them too. The alligator and dog transformations have some extra shots, there's a whole cutscene of Aya falling into the sewer that I don't remember ever actually happening in-game, and the scene with pregnant Eve in the museum is significantly longer, among other things.

posts.com:
PS1:

Crash 3 was the most fun platformer, Spyro 1 was the most comfy.

Brave Musashi is really cool and unique but can also be kind of hank. The platforming parts can suck. Save state use recommended just for the lame platforming.

I love Mega Man Legends but some people on here hate it.

Symphony of the Night deserves the hype.

Breath of Fire 3 is more complete than 4. If you want to play FF9, use the moguri mod on pc, turn on turn based mode, it speeds up the game dramatically. Star Ocean 2 is awesome, the rest of the entire series is trash.

Mr Domino and Incredible Crisis are games that don't need to be beaten, but should at least be played once.

Policenauts is a quick romp.

>>9481825
>It's pretty janky. 30 is alright though.

The problem with overclocking the original Star Fox is how the game is tied to the framerate. the game music is timed to the games crap framjerate. For example, Star Fox on real hardware:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zaWPTnHUEAY
(note how the intro cut sscene ends at the right music cue)

30fps overclock:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gZ6pWTe-Sd8

Polygon cutscene ends way before the music ends. The devs designed Star Fox around its awful framerate. In order to make Star Fox look right at 60fps, the game would have to be modified to match the timing of the new framerate. I always heard that EAD synced the first stage Corneria to Dire Straights Money for Nothing (not sure what cut).The giant robots that are carrying items in the stage are suppose to be a reference to the two CG 'movers' in the original Dire Straights music video.

https://youtu.be/lAD6Obi7Cag?t=89
https://youtu.be/zaWPTnHUEAY?t=343

posts.com:
Why hasn't anyone ever attempted to port Snatcher to the SEGA 32X CD?
The SEGA CD version is great, especially with the added light gun support that the PC Engine CD version lacked.
However, the SEGA CD version has much less colours and has been graphically downgraded compared to the PC Engine CD version because the Genesis can output much less colours at a time compared to the PC Engine.
There's also the issue of minor censorship in the SEGA CD version.

Restoring the uncensored content is one thing, but it would be much harder to restore the higher colour depth of the PC Engine CD to the SEGA CD without having to port it to the 32X.

>>9488503
The SEGA CD version has many changes from the PC Engine CD version. Even the soundtrack is different.
Also, there's no light guns for the PC Engine, but the SEGA Genesis does.

The Genesis version is a mostly superior version of Snatcher, aside from the lower colour depth and some censorship.
It's also impossible to do a fan translation of the PC Engine CD version unless you can somehow hack the game to have properly synced English subtitles.
The SEGA CD version was specifically made to give the game an international English release.

>>9494557

I tried playing this game through all the way to the end, and I can't decide if I like it or not. nThe first D is a Myst clone, but has a horror theme. It's one of those point and click FMV games. D2 tries to be a point and click FMV style game, but with real time polygons. The original D2 was being planned for the Panasonic M2 and was a completely different game. That one was scrapped and Warp started over with a new game for the Dreamcast. the game is set in some Canadian wasteland... NWT? IDK... and there are three game modes. One is the 'in-door' mode that plays 100% like a point and click mist game with real time polygons. There's the game map area, where you can run around freely a bit, and hunt for food, using a hunting system. There's the combat system that plays almost like a light gun game. Was this game meant to use a light gun? For point and click adventure games, Snatcher on the CD added a light gun and so did Policenauts on the PS1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thread for introducing anon's to classic point & click adventure games.

>What qualifies as a classic point & click adventure game?
Games which are first person or isometric, which require movement or progression from using a pointer to advance, pick up objects, and/or solve puzzles. They can be 2D sprites, FMV, or 3D.

>POINT OF THIS THREAD
If you are a P&C virgin, or are somewhat new to P&C games, or simply don't care but would be interested in exploring more of them, this thread is for you. Just ask for recc's for anything in particular.

>RESOURCES
UNIVERSAL HINT SYSTEM - If you are forced cheat and look up the solutions to puzzles, do it through this website. It does not give you the answer to puzzles outright, instead opting to give you more and more detailed hints, and has virtually every single classic, as well as many new, P&C games.
https://www.uhs-hints.com/

ADVENTURE GAME DATABASE - Has nearly every single adventure game you could possibly think of, with the genre's they belong to, screenshots, availability, platforms, development info, and a summary of the game.
https://www.adventuregamedb.com

DEAD END GUIDES - Websites which blatantly state all the known dead-end states in the most well-known Sierra franchises.
https://kingsquest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_end
https://policequest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_End
https://spacequest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_End

>NOTABLE DESIGNERS
Roberta Williams
Tim Schafer
Al Lowe
Ron Gilbert
The Coles (Corey Cole, Lori Ann Cole)
Steve Meretzky

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490850
>That should be the one thing Point and Click games should have going for them in exchange for 0 action.
Where to start, where to start...
1 - No, it isn't, why would time and events matter at all if there is "zero action"? The most someone would expect from a game with zero action should be characters, then story, then plot, then animation, then world-building.

2 - Puzzle solving is action. Not all action needs to be combat based with megaman-esque "SHOOT THE THING TILL IT DIES!" or Ninja Gaiden-esque "SLASH THE THING TILL IT DIES!" gameplay, you zoomer.

3 - I have no idea what you're talking about in regards to point and click games having "Zero action". Even if you don't include puzzle solving, for some bizarre reason, there's still plentiful examples, such as the Quest for Glory games, the Conquests games, the Indiana Jones games, Even in games with no combat mechanics, you still directly and indirectly "fight" various enemies, such as in King's Quest 1 where you fight/defeat a Giant (which you defeat with a slingshot), a Dragon (which you defeat with a bucket of water), a Troll (which you defeat with a goat), and a Witch (which you push into a boiling cauldron), and there's examples like this in most point and click games.

But even still, going back to your original point, Quest For Glory 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 all have a consistent time-based events system. The Colonel's Bequest is another one, along with Conquests of the Longbow. Even Secret of Monkey Island has combat in it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9482451
A short game with good atmosphere and great soundtrack.

Reading through the replies though. It is not like the later games or anything like the genre it created. It's a turn based real time game. It's more fun in single player. Playing Warrior without magic or a bow for ranged attacking is braindead. It's old in it's way it expects players to adapt. You can find traces of Jagged Alliance on how to deal with various combinations of enemy AIs. Very simple, but sped up due to real time clickety click and fun.

It wasn't designed with 100h playtime in mind. Mods for faster walking, Adria near town center and higher difficulties in single player are good. Expansion Hellfire is garbage.

Have fun. If you don't just leave it. It was big back then, but games were different in the 90ties.

A couple tips:

Hold shift to attack while standing in place. This is super useful for corralling monsters on one side of a doorway while you stand on the other side whacking them one on one.

If you see a dying villager outside of the church that means you got a quest called The Butcher. Somewhere on level 2 you will see a small room, when you open it he will come out and wreck your shit. The easiest way to kill him is to lead him to a spot where one or two grates are next to a door. Go through the door, slam it in his face, and then pepper him with bow shots while he walks back and forth like a retard. It'll take a while, but it's foolproof.

>>9489563
Monster Rancher Explorer and Solomon GBC as games are identical, down to the story, characters, and general gameplay. The only thing that changed was the cover art and the title screen. Even internally in the game's ROM, the game has assets for both versions (see image).

Japanese version opens with this, clearly establishing it as a prequel set 35 years before Monster Farm (Monster Rancher) in Sekitoba's Mountain.
>モンスターファームの じだいより
>35ねんほど まえのこと・・・

JP game logo is "Solomon" and a key, establishing it as the third game in Solomon's Key series. The series' branding wasn't well established in the West (where the second game is only called that in Europe, while called "Fire 'n Ice" in the American version) and the whole point behind the Monster Rancher reskin (even in Japan) was to introduce it to new audiences, so they chose to focus more on the Monster Rancher part.
The game always had the Monster Rancher license even in Japan.

It's a really good game.

>similar to Wario Blast
It's rather similar to what nip developers used to do for their obscure puzzle franchises: make new entries in the series but market them as spinoffs of more successful properties.
- Nintendo / Panel De Pon : Pokémon Puzzle League, Yoshi no Panepon / Tetris Attack
- Atlus / Puzzle Boy (aka Kwirk): "Shin Megami Tensei - Devil Children: Puzzle de Call" (spinoff of a spinoff)
- Konami / Taisen Puzzle Dama (aka Let's Attack! Crazy Cross): Twinbee/Tokimemo themed entries

>>9490682
Crazy Castle series is Kemko, not Konami.
Kemko never touched Tiny Toons Adventures.

The Crazy Castle series was for the most part Kemko jumping from movie license to movie license, and buying new movie licenses for each region whenever that region had that character already licensed by another company.

It begun in Japan with Roger Rabbit, then they lost the license but got Mickey Mouse and kept it somehow for 5 games. They tried to localize these in the USA but couldn't (a prototype for Crazy Castle Mickey Mouse 3 exists in English) except for the last one and only because Nintendo offered to publish it AND already had the Mickey license in the USA and Europe AND was interested in a quick buck before the license expired.
Kemko's backup plan to be able to release these game in the USA was to buy the Bugs Bunny license. Which lasted two games then they lost it. But it was alright because they couldn't use the Japanese versions of Crazy Castle Mickey Mouse 1 and 2 when they lost the Japanese Mickey Mouse license, so they used Japanese versions of the Bugs Bunny versions of those. THEN they reacquired the Bugs Bunny license for all three regions and made two more games, then lost it and got the Woody Woodpecker license for the final game.

To fill in for the lost Bugs Bunny license, they used a combination of other licenses in the USA and Europe for the other games like Garfield, Hugo, Ghostbusters, an original IP for once - Kid Klown (ditched after ONE game) AND... Mickey Mouse in Europe for ONE game they were able to get the Mickey Mouse rights for again, then lost it and released it again as another game.

Those licenses were not the issue, they were properly licensed.
The issue was an entire series that's all asset flips, same game but 3 different versions, and one of those games' programming is an unathorized rip-off of a european game.

>>9494253
He reused the plot too, and talked like an idiot in interviews about how the game's plot is a continuation of the Fire Emblem series set in a fourth continent and exploring the story of the Manakutes.
He really went and ported Fire Emblem 64 to the PlayStation 1 while leaving the original N64 team and project in disarray. Sometimes during the development he realized this was a very bad idea and cut like 50 characters completely from the game and changed the game engine "for some reason".

Original creators quitting and redoing the same thing better elsewhere isn't unheard of, you have the Valken devs at Masaya who were frustrated with all the rushed development and joined Squaresoft to do Front Mission Gun Hazard, and Masaya, as furious as they were, could only rip off Front Mission 2 in return. You have the Mega Man guy (not Inafune) doing Little Samson. You have the Strider guy doing Cannon Dancer/Osman.

That Fire Emblem 64 lawsuit was pivotal not just as a legal precedent of what you could do, but also for what you could NOT do as a disgraced creator who wants to go to greener pastures and make a spiritual successor. That 76 million yen fine was because you could not just steal the character designs, so much plot points it's a continuation basically, the entire universe too, talk about it as if basically a continuation, and use confidential development materials from your past job while you're at it. Notice how Mighty No. 9, Bloodstained, Gunvolt, Eiyuden Saga, and so many others are very careful to use their entirely new universes and characters.

Sure, the N64 was hard to develop for, and Nintendo's budget and schedule cuts made Genealogy half of what it could have been, but they gave him his chance, and he should have known better than to accept Famitsu (actually lackeys of Sony) offers to publish the game for him and market it as a Sony own over Nintendo. It's a trademark arrogant Sony move. You can't just expect Nintendo to lose a *first party IP*

For AC3 and up
right arm weapon (Square): Left Mouse Button
left arm weapon(Circle): Right Mouse Button
Move forward/backward (D-Up/D-Down): W, S
Strafe Left/Right (L1/L2): A, D
Look Up/Down (L2, R2): Mouse Y-Axis (-)/(+) (in that order)
Look Left/Right (D-Left/D-Right): Mouse X-Axis (-)/(+)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played the PS1 game when I was like... 7 years old, and I really liked building my robot. That stuff was really compelling. The customisation is the real meat on the bones of this game, which is fortunate because the gameplay itself was pretty weak. But in fairness, I can't criticise it too harshly for that, it's only like when you play a mediocre RPG because you still get that nice dopamine hit from getting sweet loot.

To me, a real mech game should have a cockpit view and obtuse controls that make you really feel like you're a PILOT, not just that you're playing as a sentient robot. If they can pull off something that feels a bit more realistic and less weeby, I might be more interested.

But yeah, I think there are a lot of hipsters who claim the game is better than it is because it's FromSoft, much like with King's Field. I find it funny because they act like FromSoft have always had this enlightened genius game design when in reality, like most successes, Dark Souls was just kind of a lucky experimental combination of the right ingredients.

OP is a shit troll but in all honesty it does kind of surprise me Fromsoftware was able to not only survive as long as they did with pretty much AC being their flagship franchise but they also survived a long time where as most or perhaps all companies that were in their tier died, then From goes on to be without a doubt one of the top tier companies in gaming for many years on after Dark Souls. And especially now with ER the mass of normies most certainly have to see From as one of gamings top premiere companies out there.

Its really a wild and very deserved story of success imo. Going from being the King's Field and AC devs to then hitting there stride with the Souls formula and getting themselves out of that perception of being a lower tier company. I guess filling in that mecha niche helped them to be carried as you put it. Just think of all those other companies that were in their shoes at one point. Most didn't make it to today. They either got bought out and completely gutted until they were a soulless in name only company or they just were outright made defunct. Lets take EA for example, you got Bioware which was actually honestly at the time of EA's acqusition a much bigger and more known company than From. People loved Bioware even prior to EA. Then you also had Lionhead which practically nobody even remembers today as its just a defunct company. From though? They somehow outlasted so many of their peers despite not being top tier for most of their history.

I hated my time with Armored Core (Nexus)... until

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9483981
You just let the OPL desktop software a folder on your computer (mine's on a laptop) and set it up to be sharable. Pic related, there's only three folders you care about and the full art asset set can be downloaded pre-formatted at under 200mb

From my cheat sheet:

>04/26/2021

>This is a SHARED FOLDER FOR OPEN PS2 LOADER, CONNECTED VIA ETHERNET CABLE
>-I configured a static IP address on my network adapter for this; you'll have
>to go to network and sharing > change adapter settings > ethernet > IPV4
>to convert it back to dynamic IP from current static

>I changed share settings for home and public; might want to lock those back down.

>If you want to remove the shared file path (C:\***\PS2SMB), go to properties/sharing/advanced sharing/uncheck 'share this folder'

>>9484165
>>9484171
OPL is short for Open PS2 Loader. It's software you run on your PS2 that lets you boot games from an internal hard drive, a USB drive or via your network using SMB.
It's pretty sweet, honestly. You can buy a memory card online for maybe $15 tops that's preloaded everything you need to run it on your PS2. You just plug the memory card into either slot before the console boots and you're good to go.
Setting up OPL itself is another matter entirely, but it's really well documented.

posts.com:
>>9484165
>>9484417
It's also an accompanying managerial application what you use to properly format ISOs (IE, make sure they're named with the proper formatting), manage art assets, and convert CD-format PS2 games (Bin+cue) to ghetto ISOs you can play through the utility

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484643
>Is there any difference between the IDE to SATA converters? Obviously it's all chinkshit, but is it all pretty much the same?
I noticed there's some that don't have the master/slave switch. This is a thing I became aware while homebrewing my Xbox. I don't know if that would cause any problems. Due to the low price the only option is just to try them out.

>I think I saw that you could use a 3.5 or a 2.5 drive, but I assume a 2.5 would be better for the space. I just don't know what all of this looks like once its in the guts of the machine.
I use SATA drives (2.5 ones). This is how it looks. It kind of dangles from the network adapter. As long as you're not moving the PS2 around there is no danger of it falling off. Somebody sold 3D printer "holders" to make it more sturdy, but I haven't had any problems in a year of using this setup.

>And for HDDs, is there an upper limit on specs that the PS2 even benefits from?
I think the limit is 2 TB but that's really overkill. The main issue is that any HDD you obtain has to be detectable by the PS2 for formatting. It may well be that the expensive HDD you buy simply won't be detected and there is nothing you can do. My suggestion is to salvage some SATA HDDs from old laptops or second-hand stores. I got two 500 GB and one 320 GB drives this way and only cost me $30 from a guy on facebook marketplace. All of them worked, luckily.

The PS2 won't benefit from higher speeds since most games have tied logic to the PS2 reading speed, so its capped.

The current program used for feeding games to the drive is called HDL-Batch. It has been updated this year and I literally used it yesterday. Now it has an user interface and can tell you if the ISO is corrupt or if its already in the drive etc. You format the drive in the PS2, get it out and connect it to the PC with an USB to SATA cable (very cheap), the program dectects the drive and you just select the games you want to install.

>>9484864
>Would a 3.5" drive still dangle, or sit more flush?
The 3.5 IDE drive will just fill the space so there would be no dangling. The space was made for those in mind.
I opted for the 2.5 SATA drives due to the issues of:
- needing the SATA to IDE adapter OR the original PS2 network adapter.
- needing to get an IDE to USB for the PC (the IDE needs it's own power so it will turn on in the Xbox/PS2 but not when you connect it to the PC with the SATA to IDE adapter).
- the internet scared me with stories of IDE drives dying out of the blue.
- the current abundance of SATA drives being thrown for pennies by people who don't know better and me being unable to find an IDE drive that wasn't being sold full-price/new.

>Oh, you don't just do all that through Explorer file management? I guess I didn't notice that when reading this stuff.
Windows will just not even acknowledge you added connected a drive if it's formatted for PS2. Yes. It's confusing.

posts.com:
>>9485430
Obviously the hard drive goes in the PS2.
OPL has an option to format it for PS2 use, regardless what was in it before.
It just needs to recognize it (there's a website for compatibilities but its incomplete and given the unlikeness of finding the exact drive it's better to get it for cheap).

Once formatted you can add games to it. The fastest is to take the drive out and connect via USB to the PC.
Windows won't recognize the drive, but if you use HDL batch it will appear there. There you just select the ISOs and BIN/CUEs you want to add and it loads them up.
There are other ways to add stuff like network or USB but that's slow as fuck.

>>9485789
It couldn't hurt to grab a game or two that you're interested in since there's still some good stuff that can be had for cheap out there, but if I were you I would throw CFW on your new PS2 and get some way to play ISOs going. You'd definitely get the most games for your money that way, and 99% of stuff works exactly the same as it would from a real CD or DVD with a little bit of setup.
If you read this thread there have been several posts with good resources about where to get started. Basically, you'll need a memory card with Free MCBoot preinstalled (you can get these on eBay or Amazon) and you'll need to install OPL Manager on your PC to manage your games. If you have a fat PS2, you should spend a little more money and get a hard drive set up for it. If you have a slim you should stick to playing games over ethernet. You can play games over USB on ether model, but it's not as good as the other methods.

>>9493123
I think it's a matter of people wanting a hassle free solution, like the original xbox or wii. I have around 950 PS2 games on my 2TB HDD and just a couple of games didn't work, which was solved by using an older version of OPL.

OPL has some plugins enabled by default and even though they can be useful, it breaks a good % of games. One unlocks the read speed of the HDD so games load as fast as possible and the other is called IGR (In-Game Reset), which enables you to reset the console with a combination of buttons. For games that don't boot, you have to turn off one of these plugins. Problem is, many people don't know you can have game-specific configs, so they see a game that doesn't work and call it quits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9494125
>The level design looks generic, lazy, and chaotic


Vectorman is in that wired genre of game that isn't quite a run and run, and isn't quite a platformer. I generally call these types of games 'gun-formers'. Gunformers, are the types of games that feature maze like level design with lots of platforming and your primary weapon being projectile. Turrican was kinda the type of game that spawned this genre. I would say Metroid, but Metroid has too much exploration to fall into this category. Robocop vs Terminator, Judge Dredd (SNES game), Cool Spot, because you shoot all the time, Earthworm Jim 1 at least, Alien 3 Mega Drive/ Genesis, Demolition Man. I'm sure others can think of more. That's the genre I put Vectorman in, as most of the levels follow that formula. Vectorman tries to mix it up with different formulas, though. Game looks really nice, it has a generally good soundtrack (to me), the levels are good. Some bosses are cool looking. But some are way to gimicky. Like the train boss is not good. the disco stage boss where you spin around in circles is a bit lame. It's OK for one of these games. But Hard Corps is better overall. Contra III on the SNES is better. I remember playing Vectorman 2 all the way up to the half way point, but never fully completed it. Vectorman 2 is a spectacle for the hardware, with enhanced simulated lighting and bigger sprites, it is an impressive tech demo for the hardware in 1996. Anyway. Not too bad as a sequel. I feel like the levels were a little more streamlined, but the game made harder. It has the generic 3D tunnel effect stage, found in all of the Genesis/ Mega Drive games, like Garfield and batman and Robin. Also wasn't a fan of the over head stages with the rocket. I rank it as B tier series. Pixar stole the concept for Wall-E?

https://youtu.be/5qixxon3MY4?t=1062

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9492893
You see, the most important aspect of Wipeout 2097 is lap times, because AI speed is timer-based. Crafts in pole position get a significant speed boost, which gets gradually slowed down as the final lap approaches.

What's more, is that AI is also given an abundance of missiles, mines and electrobolts by the end of the race, and will target *exclusively* the player craft. This makes it hard to get good times in the final laps, and stacks the deck against the player to the point a counterbalance is needed.

This is where autopilot and speedboost pick ups come in. They are a good way to gain that precious extra second, either by the beginning or end of the race, to ensure you will have at least a small winning chance. This becomes more relevant if you are flying a slower craft like Feisar on tracks like Odessa Keys and Vostok Island, where practically every second counts and bumping chances are very high.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It would be the best game on SNES if:

100%ing the game wasn't made needlessly obnoxious by some bad design choices, namely having to collect everything in a level in one go, instead of only coming back for the things you missed previously, and the presence of stuff like missable red coins carried by Shy Guys that escape or one way doors and tubes that exacerbate the problem.

The extra levels weren't mostly infuriating bullshit.

The transformations weren't clunky and honestly unnecessary. It's fine when they're in self contained sub-levels when you have to fly the helicopter in the middle of a level avoiding enemies and trying to not miss collectables it's just obnoxious.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9494223
Yoshi's Island is weird because if you don't bother with the collectables you can fly through it in like 4 hours, and it's braindead easy - However, you'll also miss a lot of the best bits of design in the game.
If you DO bother with the collectables and try to 100% it, you will absolutely fucking hate Yoshi's Island by the end.

So when I play usually I just try to go for all the flowers and don't really bother with much else.

It's a great game. The fact that they just pulled that aesthetic out of the air and nailed it on the first try is remarkable to me. It also has an insanely high amount of enemies, including reintroducing Shy Guys to the Mario series which is pretty neat.

DKC and Yoshi's Island both came out relatively late in the SNES's lifespan and are both great platformers, but they're so utterly different from each other. That era was really the pinnacle of the genre for a long time.

Anyway here's a scrapped stage select that was uncovered during the gigaleak.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Nintendo 64 games run at high resolution
Majority of N64 games run at standard 320x240 resolution. Some games support higher resolution with the expansion pack but less than a dozen reach 640x480. For the rest it's some weird resolution like 400×440 or 480x360.
https://nintendo.fandom.com/wiki/Nintendo_64_Expansion_Pak
>Nintendo 64 games have higher polygon count than PS1 games
N64 supports 160000 polygons per second with standard microcode. If you switch off some hardware features like Z-buffering, N64 theoretically can reach 500000-600000 polygons per second but these would be very basic unfiltered and untextured polygons.
PS1 has 180000 for textured polygons and 360000 polygons per second for untextured polygons. Most games use a combination of two.
In practice, no N64 game has a polycount outside of PS1 capabilities.
>Nintendo 64 games have bad textures because of cart size limitations
Only partially true. The most significant bottleneck is 4kb texture cache which takes CPU cycles to be updated. In short, the bigger textures you use, the worse framerate you have.

>>9471772
>I'm playing MRA2 as well. Do you have any tip for a first-timer?
Nothing really specific to this games campaign as I haven't really bothered with finding many secrets or anything, but some basic tips on raising monsters, you may already know all this but....

Always make sure you relieve monsters "stress" and "fatigue", always let it rest obviously but also use items like oil or mintcandy to remove fatigue after training and battles. Battling itself actually helps remove monsters stress. As you accumulate larger amounts of cash, it's definitely good to prioritize buying all the more expensive stress relieving, fatigue relieving, and sleep helping items you'll see in the shop like the cups and gems, as can afford them of course, don't skip out on them, they'll make it easier for new monsters. Also don't let your monster get fat or malnourished, fat monsters get fatigued more and underweight monsters get stressed more.

Also take it easy on baby monsters, just do the most basic training until its more mature aka when Holly tells gives you that cue that it's an "important time" or whatever she says, that's when you start the coach routines

Always focus on like 3, maybe 4 main stats to train your monster in. Having a balanced monster doesn't really work because there's only so much time you can put into training during its lifespan, you want your monster to excel hard in specific areas, not be average in many areas, so take that into consideration when deciding what monster you wanna raise and how you want it to grow/what moves you want it to learn

When you're stronger and start doing sparring with the intention of learning new moves specifically, it's not really worth it unless you're gonna learn a new move, so don't bother wasting the money and time unless it says there's a chance your monster will learn a new move, and honestly I say theres no shame in saving before and restarting until you learn the move

I just think guest cap should increase proportionate to a ride's length up to like 300 meters. A 300+ length ride gets its full guest draw, an amount shorter gets a proportionally reduced amount of guests to the park as a mini-ride merits. But any sweeping balance changes like this would need to be an optional checkbox for me to be okay with modifying the game so heavily.

Yeah, that's a bald-headed lie. I did the math for shits and giggles. Built a helix stack with a station at top and bottom, took ride length for that segment over number of turns to get circumference and hence radius of curvature: 11.8m. Convert 130kph to m/s and a = v^2/r = 11.2g.

Taking a two-unit (3m) high volume of space to be a cube, a medium turn spans, square-center to square-center, 5 squares for a 15m diameter and 17.7g.
