posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's not as popular now as it used to be, but it's still alive. Every version has at least one private server.

Most populated servers for each version:
Dreamcast: Sylverant https://sylverant.net
Gamecube: Schthack https://schtserv.com
Xbox: Schthack https://schtserv.com
PC: Ephinea https://ephinea.pioneer2.net

Gamecube and Xbox are similar enough to crossplay, and they just got it working mere weeks ago. But Dreamcast and PC versions are too different from the others for crossplay to work.

PC is the most popular version these days, and in some ways the best one, as it's the only one with Episode 4.

If you want to play on a console, I'd recommend the Gamecube version on a Wii. Dreamcast is missing Episode 2. Getting ethernet hardware for either Dreamcast or Gamecube is expensive. Cheaper on an Xbox obviously, but that's still a little glitchy - I see Xbox players disconnecting a lot.

Wii is cheap and easy to hack (https://wii.guide), only requires a USB adapter for ethernet, which you can find for $10 on Ebay (although make sure you get the right one). Once you have that, the homebrew app Nintendont will load the game and emulate the Broadband Adapter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9473260
Absolutely. Especially if you can get friends in on the splitscreen multiplayer. One of the things that impressed me most about PSO on GCN is that everyone can have their own characters on their own memory cards, and are completely independent. If you start a party with friends in FF Crystal Chronicles, your character is stuck in that party. In PSO though, you can play with one group of friends one day, and then take your memory card and use the same character with a completely different group of friends the next day. 4 players can play together with 4 different characters on 4 different memory cards, even though the gamecube only has 2 memory card ports.

One caveat though; the camera sucks in split screen. Don't jump straight into multiplayer with four level 1 characters. Everyone should play a bit of single player first to get used to playing the game before their screen gets shrunk down to one-quarter of the screen. And to get some money for restocking healing items.

>>9473758
Snippet:
>Interviewer: Obviously, Diablo was a big influence on PSO. How much of Diablo did you play yourself?
>I played quite a lot. Nobody on our team had worked on an online game, so one of the challenges was getting the team to understand what made online games fun. I had a lot of people play the game, but a lot of them were turned off by the dark fantasy. They would say, “it’s disturbing,” or, “I don’t get why it’s fun.” Trying to unify the team and getting them to understand the direction we wanted to take the game in was very difficult.

>Interviewer: Did you have LAN parties, where you played in a controlled environment so that the team could understand the cooperative elements?
>We installed Diablo on everyone’s PC in the office and had a closed LAN and spent many days playing together so that the team could learn what network gaming was all about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9473764
>Interviewer: Was there a point where you saw people starting to get the appeal, like the satisfaction of seeing a rare item drop, where you felt the team really get into the game?
>Some people like Setsumasa stayed around until 10 or 11 p.m. at night after people left the office. He would connect Diablo to the network and play until morning, wake up to work, and then play again. Some of us weren’t going home much at the time. Some people would go home just to bathe, sleep a few hours, come back into the office to work, and then play Diablo at the office. It was mostly in the name of research, though. There are a number of games that we used as inspiration. Diablo was obviously one of them. I had heard that Dragon Quest was inspired by remaking Ultima with a Japanese audience in mind. So our concept was, “Let’s make a Diablo game that would appeal to the Japanese audience.”

>Interviewer: With good results. Even though Diablo is a distinctly American game, PSO feels like a very distinctly Japanese game. And yet, it’s not just palatable to Japanese gamers but to everyone.
>I think Diablo is an amazing game, but it’s not a game that appeals to Japanese players. Our suspicion was that Japanese gamers would prefer to cooperate and work together to defeat something more than to compete and fight against other players. That’s why we created PSO to be a cooperative role-playing game. Diablo has cooperative elements but it also has PK and an element of killing other player characters. We eliminated those elements and focused on how we could make a fun, cooperative RPG experience. I think that’s the biggest difference between PSO and Diablo.

I was pretty stupid when I first played PSO. I loved the aesthetics, the world was super cool, and teaming up with my friends to play together was great. I remember all of us getting set up on PC and when all of us were there, we played through either a space station (tutorial?) or the area shown here >>9471891 and it was a fun time until the leader of our party suggested we play the same dungeon again. Then again, and again. I recall we had played the same area for around 2 hours before I asked if we could move on, to which the party leader said we weren't really ready for the next area and that we'd need to go through a few more times. It was the first time I can remember experiencing grinding in a video game.

I remember playing on my own after, and making it easily through the next area, but I didn't have experience with these types of games, nor did I really get the whole dungeon-looting loop since I had mostly played linear games that didn't require grinding before that. I fell off, sadly, but I'll always appreciate the atmosphere this series set up with its cool designs, great music, etc. I gave PSU a shot when that came out, I think in a demo version, and it somehow landed with me more than PSO did at the time, but I think it's just simply because I wasn't as stupid with game genres anymore. Maybe I should try PSO again sometime.

>>9491527
I wish I could recommend you a guide, but nothing really clicked for me and I eventually just fucked around for a year until I got the basics down. I use and have always used REAPER as a DAW. It will tell you it's not free, but it will always be free. The only things I recommend you looking up a guide/video for is how to install vst (essentially a plug in that defines what ever kind of sound you are making), where to get free vsts, and how to open up piano roll (this is a visual interface that is laid out like a piano where you can just drag and drop the notes and how long you want them to be.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9493163
nta but an experienced computer musician. having a physical keyboard isn't necessary by any means BUT a) it can help with your learning, as it's a useful tool for visualizing and intuiting musical concepts as you learn them, and b) as you get more knowledgeable and experienced it's a great way to get a more human and natural sound if you record midi from it as opposed to mouse clicking out a melody or progression on the grid of the piano roll. also nice to have around for tinkering around and figuring out melodies and progressions you might want to expand into an actual track.

>>9491174
honestly one of the best tips I have is to not use base famitracker. Use a fork like Dn-famitracker or something because base famitracker is super clunky. Once you've gotten a good version of famitracker, fuck around with automating instruments and fuck around with different parameters and stuff. The more you experiment, the more you'll learn. Music theory will come with studying pieces you like and by fucking around and finding what you like.

It depends I guess if you actually want experience in an instrument or just want to jump into writing music.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9494025
Speaking from another rookie anon's perspective..
You can't go wrong with Surge, it's a fucking beast of a synth. Yoshimi (and ZynAddSubFx) is not bad either, incredibly versatile but harder to work with in my experience. Honorable mention for Helm as it also seems good if you're willing to fiddle with it but i wasn't impressed with the presets it had.
It can depend on what you're trying to make, too, VSTs that emulate vidya console soundcards tend to be free and even if they aren't you always have the option of using soundfonts. And if you wanna get percussion-related stuff, samples can work fine enough or better than a VST in some instances. You should just pirate stuff here and there, though, especially if there's specific sounds in songs you're looking to replicate, trying to get synths to sound the exact way you want tends to be a frustrating process and may get in the way of you learning other things

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490142
anon, even the best-optimized 3D games on it had low framerates and low res. and most of them were crappy racers with tiny drawing distance.
i think there's a whole breed of retards who think GBA being 32 bit meant it had same specs as PSX, and that Nintendo just "didn't work hard enough on 3d". except unlike PSX, GBA had no real GPU or 3D hardware. if you understand what this means, you know you will need the CPU to render everything, and it will be done at a very slow speed.
pair this with the need for batteries, tiny res, lack of analog, etc., and you will understand why it didn't have much 3D.
and yes, surely, 20 years later some dedicated autists managed to put Tomb Raider on GBA, but no one would have time and money to bother with this back in the day when the system's life cycle was only 3 years.
instead, you got smooth good 2D and actually good 2D games. virtually of the 3D GBA titles I've played were shovelware racers, gimmicky trash and yuroshit. so I'm glad that GBA devs went with 2D instead of chasing 3D.

Panzer Dragoon Saga? As a Rail-Shooter? Have you played it? Its is most definitely not a rail shooter.

Sin and Punishment is and excellent somewhat lesser known rail shooter for the n64, as it was an import. It quite unique because you’re on foot and theres tons of different mechanics than the typical flying rail shooter. Even pokemon snap is playable for a few hours of casual fun. RVPGDH

>>9484740
I don't know if this is due to localization, but I always found Kefka's characterization post-WoR to be a bit weird. For most of the game he's a gleeful, sadistic psychopath who delights in making others suffer before ultimately killing them. His willing, knowing destruction of the world aligns with this, even if it appears to have been done on a whim. Now he has ultimate power to make the world an utterly miserable place for everyone, and he can kill and destroy anything and anyone with but a thought. But when you go to face him, he starts with brooding nihilistic shit he never brought up before, about how clinging to life is stupid if people know they're ultimately gonna die, etc. Then your party gives their reasons for going on living, and the mask comes off and he's back to having fun with taking "precious lives", but not before stating his ultimate objective is to just outright destroy everything, which would leave him without purpose or lives to end for his amusement. So, what's his deal? Is he just so powerful in his insanity that he stopped giving a shit?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485826
My girlfriend and I both got Covid back in November of 2020 and we were both quarantined from work for a solid four weeks. Paid, thankfully, but horribly sick for the first week and a half. I got better quicker and I occupied our time by playing Ty the Tasmanian Tiger. Now whenever snow hits our area she wants me to play it again. Plan on starting it in a few days. Other games we usually play around this time of year are Ms. Pacman Maze Madness and Spyro Enter the Dragonfly. I personally have an attachment to that game because as a kid I was really poor, and my original Spyro games had been lost and I couldn't afford to get new copies, so one of the last Christmases I had with my gram before she died, she got me a secondhand Gamecube and a few games, EtD being one of them. She knew how much I loved Spyro when I was younger, and I was happy to have any title at all again, so I played the whole game over the next few visits while she watched. Sorry for blogposting. Happy Holidays anons.

The neat thing here is it's not always the same enemies in the same patterns.
If you do really well against one type of enemy, the game shifts it's strategy and throws other shit at you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For example, if you wreck ass on the the round things, it'll start throwing the 'bats' at you, and if you wreck ass on them, it'll start throwing the 'fast movers' at you.
I dunno what any of this shit is called that's just what I call them.
These red and white cross looking things, you can't tell it, but they're moving top-right to bottom-left so fast I'm totally boned here, they move in straight lines, but they're so fast that if you're in their line when they start, you can't get out of the way, they just kamikaze your ass.

>>9491981
Fair warning, HP1 on ps2 is rough, iirc 1 and 2 were developed by two different devs, but used Chamber of Secrets engine.
PS2's Philosopher's Stone also came out in 2003, a year After the PS2 version of Chambers, pretty late compared to the ps1 version, and the film.
My guess is, EA wanted to bank on the PS1 version's success so they pushed out the ps2 version quickly by using the assets of Chambers, and it shows. I still enjoyed it but it's a big downgrade from Chambers despite coming out after it.
Philosopher's Stone and Chamber of Secrets on PS1 are pretty fun, the pacing for PS1 Chambers is excellent, imo.
Something I liked about PS2's Philosopher's Stone over PS2's Chambers are the placement of the loading screens, but it comes at a cost. if you play both you'll see what I mean. PS2 Chambers is overall more polished and smoother.
One thing you'll most likely hate about PS2's Philosopher's Stone are the Bertie Bott's Every Flavor Beans pick up in this game, someone thought it was a good idea to have Harry comment on the flavor EVERY, SINGLE, TIME you pick them up.
>UGH SARDINE FLAVOR
>HMMMM COFFEE
>REVOLTING! VOMIT FLAVOR!!
>HMMM PEPPERMINT
and if you pick multiple at once, you're going to hear
>HMM-UGH-REVOLT-SARDINE-PEPPER-UGH
I hope you like hearing "A WIZARD CARD!" too, lol. it's a rough game.

And if you want to break the game's Bertie Bott's Every Flavor Beans economy, after a new day, check every school desk and Fred and George's shop-during day time, and you'll be swimming in sardine and vomit flavor beans to your heart's content. You can use that to buy yourself the Bertie Bott's Every Flavor Beans bag that lets you carry more, and you can use that to buy everything from Fred and George Weasley's shop early on, like the Wizard Cards.
You can also upgrade your health in this game but I don't think the game tell you that, I think it's earned by completing the missing objects quests or collecting wizard cards, i'm still not sure after beating it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Basically when games and technology started specifically aiming for a photorealistic picture, is when "retro" truly ended. To me what we call retro - both 2D and early 3D - is not about dates but rather about artistic merits of working around major technical limitations, which is what made those games so good. When every game looked absolutely different and unique because they were all hyper-stylized artistic depictions of reality seen through the prism of artistry of creative people. Not so much anymore when 90% of the entire development process goes towards making everything look how it does in real life - which is, you know, the same. When the 7th gen started we didn't just gain things like upgrades in storage space and resolution, for the first time in history we started progressively losing things, losing artistry, because there were no more major technical limitations to overcome. More and more elements started becoming token. So much so that we saw the rise of tertiary elements like online becoming more popular than the games themselves.

>Cinematic platformers, Mortal Kombat
Nothing even remotely like that. They used digitized actors because it was easier compared to drawing sprites. The end result was just as cartoony tho, they never even attempted to deliberately strive for any sort of photorealism.
>the whole FMV fad
That was a completely separate convergent evolutionary dead-end. There were VHS-based games and so on. At that point you can say board games are photorealistic because you played them irl.

No, only in the 7th gen did games start deliberately and en-mass, which is key here, strive for photorealism in one way or another.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484032
I wouldn't mind this definition but I also don't mind including GC/PS2/Faggotbox either. Looking back with the benefit of hindsight regarding what I hate the most about games & consoles today, I see that generation as being relatively pure. Experimental market-poking and prodding happened, but it wasn't the norm, and I fully expect to have to deal with these being called retro by my weaker brethren en masse someday.

With the Wii/PS3/Faggotbox360 they were becoming more committed to their modern, forwadd-looking hardware identity, but they were still only experimenting with the rot. It had evolved from a question of permissions to a question of facilitation. It was the Switch/PS4/FaggotboxOne generation where all three companies had fully committed to modern rot concepts. Their hardware angle was set and leaned into, their policy and strategy on the brave new werld of microtransactions, unfinished beta AAA releases, bloatgramming, and various other consumer abuses that old games lack were set and normalized.

Maybe retro can be defined by exactly in which ways companies abused consumers. Back in the day your lives were tied to a real life quarter that you popped into the machine, so the market wanted HARD games that you learned to play by dying repetitively. When the move to console came it wasn't long till this shifted. Instead of incessantly killing you (unpopular with millenials), the games were filled with meaningless content and time wasters. >Wrong. So backwards compatibility makes games not retro anymore? Ps3 plays ps1. I guess ps1 isn't retro now. Derp.
Let me rephrase it, for anons with poor reading comprehension.
Any consoles released after 1st January 2000 aren't retro. Games for these consoles released after this date would still be retro.
Final Fantasy 9 would still be a retro game since it was developed for and released for the PS1, a console that was first released in late 1994, despite the game itself being released in mid-2000.
So would Digimon World 3, despite being released in 2003.
For PC games the cut-off would be 31st December 2004, with some exceptions. Half-Life 2 can't really be considered retro, while Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines could, since it inherits so much from 2000's Deus Ex.

A new generations model, not based on years, but on hardware and gameplay:
1 - Pre-NES.
2 - NES-TG16-SMS.
3 - SNES-SMD-GB-PS1.
4 - PS1-N64-SAT.
5 - PS2-Wii era, incl. GBA and DS.
6 - PS3-360-WiiU era, incl. 3ds.
7 - Xbone-PS4 thru today.
Nintendo since Wii has dropped a generation behind the pack. I think the major problem with the previous model was basing it off of Nintendo's consoles as if they represented the pack, when really they are notable outliers. Look at them today especially, their main system is a handheld! To say the switch is the representative of modern gaming isn't entirely accurate, it more represents the previous generation's staying power.
Look at human beings. There are 4 or 5 generations living today. They are each different, but one's inception is not necessarily the other's demise. a generation lasts as long as it is able to compete for market space. 8bit did it for a whole decade on a puny B&W screen, but it stuck it out!

Games should be categorized based on the types of technology used, not arbitrary release dates. Look at the way architecture is categorized for example (Classical, Mid-century modern, Postmodern, Neomodern, New Classical, Contemporary, etc…). Mid century modern will never become classical. Similarly, Jazz music will never become classical. Its dumb to call an 8 bit hand held a later gen just because it came out later. The gamegear is literally just a master system. The Wii is literally just an overclocked gamecube and has a weaker CPU & GPU than the Xbox. Using this logic, here's the REAL gaming eras:

Pre-Retro Era:
Gen 1 - Literally just Pong
Gen 2 - Atari 2600, Vectrex, shitboxes nobody cares about

[Insert Gaming Crash Here]

Retro Era AKA The Golden Age:
Gen 3 (8 Bit) - NES, Gameboy, Gameboy Color, Master System, Game Gear, PC 88, MSX, ZX Spectrum
Gen 4 (16 bit) - SNES, GBA, Genesis, PC98, TG16, Amiga, Neo Geo
Gen 4.5 - Sega 32X
Gen 5 (32 bit 2D + Low Poly 3D) - PS1, Saturn, N64, DS
Gen 5.5 - Dreamcast, PSP, 3DS
Gen 6 (Mid Poly) - PS2, Gamecube, Wii
Gen 6.5 (High Poly, but low resolution) - Xbox

[Insert Globohomo Here]

Modern Era (HD widescreen, Microtransactions, Day 1 patches, hyper realism, Casualization, homogenized controllers, homogenized architecture, mocap, facescan, Californian management, etc...):
Gen 7 (Early HD) - 360, PS3, Vita, Wii U, Switch
Gen 8 (Gen 7 + Stable 1080p) - PS4, Xbone
Gen 8.5 (Gen 7 + 4K) - PS4 Pro, Xbone X
Gen 9 (Gen 7 + 4K + RTX) - PS5, Xbox SX

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9487747
If it was just an overlay of lines, it'd be nothing.
But a proper shader is separating red, green, and blue signals for each pixel into separate phosphors, applying distortion onto the overall image, specific blending properties based on adjacent colors, etc. And all of this has to be done to every pixel on every rendered frame.
On top of the game being played in the first place, it's a lot.

I did.
You're better off learning Japanese to get any enjoyment out of some of those.

The guy doing the second Game Boy fan translation stopped exactly because the case riddles rely heavily on Japanese wordplay that would require rewriting the whole plot / character names for that case. First Game Boy game is an alright adventure game.

I played the first GBA game (Naraweta Tantei) that plays like an action adventure game, and the language barrier starts reasonable then becomes a vertical line in the final case that, again, relies heavily on Japanese language riddles AND involves 100-ish small cards that were in the previous cases and were so far irrelevant but every single one has a Japanese wordplay puzzle. I liked it. It's by Branpesto.
Second GBA game has amazing graphics but is a visual novel on a timer. Very unfriendly for EOPs or N5ers.

PS1 game supposedly has original work by the animation studio and includes a filler case about a black organization member, that content to my knowledge is exclusive to this game and like that weird side manga have never been translated to english or acknowledged in the manga or anime, even in the filler episodes. Some people praise it. The game itself isn't very good to actually play.

Someone translated the Kindaichi x Detective Conan crossover and it's decent (albeit censored, to the point of absurdity: you're asked to notice a bloodstain that doesn't exist) it plays like a point and click detective game.

No idea about the rest. Some praise Mirapolis (Wii) and the PS2 game for their production values, and the 3DS game might or might not have had original story content, but the rest is derivative trash.

It's no adventure game classic, but I am disappointed after all these years that it wasn't better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9493759
Lots of reasons. It's been known since forever ago that Woolsey didn't deliver the most faithful translation, not to mention all the censorship, which is why we got that old Sky Render fan translation over twenty years ago (that we now know to be amateurish as fuck). Then the GBA game came out, and its translation was recognized to be much more accurate, but it had two problems: first, by that point, Woolsey's script had obtained meme status, and while the GBA script kept some of his lines, it changed or tossed enough of them out to piss a vocal part of the fanbase off. Second, the GBA version had problems of its own, namely shit music, slowdown and lower resolution, among others. So now you have a bunch of Woolsey fanboys who like the idea of a more accurate script while still staying true to the Woolsey "flavor", all on the mostly superior SNES version, and before long, we got the Ted Woolsey Uncensored hack. Problem is, its creator didn't know a lick of moon, so all he did was mix and match bits and pieces of the Woolsey, GBA and Sky Render scripts as he pleased, and to top it off, he decided to also make it an overarching "game improvement" hack that fixed a gorillion longstanding bugs and added QoL changes. This effectively set the mold for all like-minded hacks that followed, all of which were made by people with no nip-speaking credentials, and all of which were convinced they could do it better than the last, especially given they're not constrained to just script changes, but outright game changes as well, so every new release is just feature creep. It's telling that it wasn't until like last year that we got a simple, no frills port of the GBA script to the SNES version.

tl;dr autism and one-upmanship

>>9491589
4 and 5 are great, 3 is pretty good, but 12 is legitimately excellent and having just played it recently I think it's a real shame its quality gets overshadowed by >Kris. From my notes:

Played on Maniac-Classic (H2 out of H4), on a fresh file - AKA no wifi content or full reclassing unlocked.
Started right off the back of replaying shadow dragon on H5... and holy FUCK am I glad I didn't select Lunatic difficulty instead. This mother fucker is HARD; I actually encountered multiple instances where finishing a chapter left me too mentally wiped to continue.

Anyway. I'm giving this an 8/10, but understand that it's generally actually a very solid 9/10; it's just that there's some bits of it that are so god damn rigid it's like you're playing advance wars instead. Incessant sets of same-turn reinforcements in near every other map that dump like 6 promoted units on you with such sheer damage output even your power fighters can't last more than one attack; a massive 8-chapter prologue that's so claustrophobic in size and so stringent in its expectations that you simply can't beat it without resetting each chapter 20 times over to get an exact read on how the AI behaves; enemy mobilization flags triggered by arbitrary obfuscated lines in the sand at the best of times, paired with maps so devilishly designed in their overlapping cross-crossing archer and mage ranges that even the most overpowered squad of fliers I've ever seen in a FE title get put in their place... it's a fucking lot, and you ALWAYS feel the pressure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9491883
On the one hand, it's one of the most tightly crafted games I've ever seen, and particularly impressive coming off of Shadow Dragon's general careless smattering of cavaliers and knights to wing spear across a map; on the other, I don't think I've ever felt so much sheer contempt for the player in a first-party release, and it'd take a lot to convince me to go back anytime soon. And that's not even the extent of it, either; from the hole in your wallet that never once gets plugged, to the Arenas so backloaded and so rigged against you entering one is like having a dev spit directly in your eye, to an endgame that had me get trapped in a corner for half an unironic hour as I was forced to desperately dig myself out from under an avalanche of *50* fully fledged stat capped god damn dragons, there's just nothin' else like it.

And honestly? I didn't even fuckin' care about Chris. They're just a blank slate for the other characters to bounce off of, wholly inconsequential. Plus, their presence allows for a good hundred+ actual support conversations and a whole sideplot added alongside in 5 uniquely designed gaiden chapters; yeah, their hat-wearing antics are dumb, but it's an inconsequential sort of dumb. And in fact, all that content they bring - combined with the Fire Emblem BS remake content included and the sheer replayability afforded by having your nuts kicked in in with new and exciting intensity - has me honestly convinced this might be one of the most content-rich FE games out there.

>>9491895
That's 'bout it, I figure. If I *do* ever come back for lunatic, though - some notes for me.
-EXP is PLENTIFUL; by endgame you'll be forced to kill enemies with 20/20 units for lack of worthwhile trainees. Don't get obsessed.
-Money is SCARCE; if you want to arena abuse though, do it with multiple characters 5-6 times each. There's an obfuscated cap on how much it'll let you do; after x number of battles it'll secretly up the enemy scaling, until after ~10 wins or so you'll ONLY be matched with impossible battles against 0-damage generals, dracos and paladins. It'll be even worse on lunatic I'm sure - honestly best to ignore in full if you can manage, trying to brute force it ruined a good few days of my life.
-The game gives you plenty of vulns and basic weapons; don't buy any of the former, and be conservative with the latter...
-But even still, DO FORGE; you DO NOT NEED wing spears or armorslayers in this game, but a might/hitforged Dracospear'll do you good.
-And LOOK UP SPAWN LOCATIONS, TOO; for real, Anri's way and its 12-move wyvern spawns are asinine, and that moment in chapter 19 where approaching the seize zone causes 12 promoted paladins and horsemen to simultaneously spawn in a perfect circle around you is so awful it's comical.
-Make sure to keep at least ~2-3 rescue staff uses + the same number of renew uses for the last chapter; you get a second hammerne in the penultimate chapter, and WILL want to use it...
-And finally - if you want to raise alt characters (Est), reclassing to cleric honestly isn't a bad way to go. They'll keep most of the STR growth.

>>9491589
They're all worth playing out of curiosity because they're all fairly different, but not all of them are good.

First one feels barebones as expected, even if it has a decent amount of stuff for its time, and is extremely slow with annoying inventory management, but if you want to see how the series started, why not. Some broken stuff is fun to abuse.

Second one has trash maps, but at least it's different. idk, just give it a try and see if you like it, but I personally think it's average. Feels closer to a JRPG than to an actual SPRG.

Third one includes a remake of the first one which is more fun than the original imo. The new part is solid even if some early maps are a bit of a slog. Also has two of the best pegasus riders in the series which makes it very fun.

Fourth game is considered by some to be the best in the series and has a lot of unique stuff, though the huge maps can be an issue for some people. It's really an epic adventure worth playing at least once, and the best story in the franchise. Second best after Thracia imo.

Fifth one is my personal favorite and considered one of the best, it's fun as fuck with tons of cool mechanics, weapons and staves to use. Probably the best map design in the franchise too.

Sixth one is the first one made after Kaga, the creator of the series, left, and it shows. Barebones compared to the previous two. I actually prefer it to the other two GBA games because it's harder, but some maps can be tedious. Some get filtered by the low accuracy of your attacks but it's fine.

Also, play Tear Ring Saga and Berwick Saga, the games made by Kaga after he left IS. TRS is pretty much a FE game and it's better than most of the series, and BS is a contender for the title of best SPRG ever made imo, it's a masterpiece.

So if you're in a hurry, only play Genealogy, Thracia, TRS and BS, because they're very good. Then Mystery if you want more, and the first two games if you're curious, but don't expect much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
4 is defintely worth playing, as its story ambitions and scope remains impressive to this day; However, I do feel Kagafags tend to give its gameplay an unfair pass when its frankly not very interesting. I applaud its experimentation and innovation; FE was still in a phase of figuring out just what kind of game it was; but a lot of mechanics in FE4 end up completely redundant or underused to the point you wonder why they are even there. The game hands you units in the very the first map that are capable of soloing the game for you, and it continues to do this over the course of the game. The maps are filled with enormous swathes of empty spaces where nothing happens. Guarding your castle may as well not exist as a mechanic for how little it actually comes into play. Foot soldiers are hilariously gimped compared to horse units and don't get nearly enough firepower to make up for the disrepancy or inconveniance of their low movement speed. There's very little real challenge going on with the AI; The tried and true "bait an enemy with your toughest unit" strategy still works 99% of the time.

Its unfortunate, but FE4 biggest problem is that outside of its stellar presentation and plot, the game itself is kind of a boring slog. Its hard to justify playing it more than once.

It's late 1999 and the other consoles out at the time are the PS1, N64, and Saturn. Games on all of these systems either ran like crap and/or looked like crap. It feels sorta underwhelming today and nothing special, like the original SMB or Half Life, but put your head in the mindset of gamers at the time and you'll see that there was literally nothing like it and understand why it was so appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490415
The best ways to emulate PC98 in 2022 is Neko Project II Kai which is a Retroarch core.
If there is a single benefit to Retroarch is that it's ported to almost everything. If the OS of your smart TV is Android-based, then you might have some luck running PC98 games on it.
Dosbox X gave me better performance compared to Anex, but it takes a little longer to configure.
Anex was the go to PC98 emulator for a while, but it's not the case anymore since better options exist.

This is a bit misleading. The Dreamcast's real discs were a custom format with more capacity than a CD, so many (most?) games are too big to fit on a CD, and to burn them you have to use shitty scene releases that compress or remove content. You can get around this by using an ODE (optical drive emulator), but it's more expensive and complicated than just burning discs.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_of_Duke_Nukem_Forever

>The video game Duke Nukem Forever spent more than 14 years in development, from 1996 to 2011. It is a first-person shooter for Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360,[1] developed by 3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is the sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series. Intended to be groundbreaking, it became an infamous example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; it had been in development under 3D Realms since 1996. Director George Broussard, one of the creators of the original Duke Nukem game, announced the development in 1997, and promotional information for the game was released from 1997 until its release in 2011.

Your post is even more misleading. Most games can be shrunk to fit on a "standard" capacity CD without removing anything but unused space. Most of what can't will fit on a larger capacity CD, which are easily obtainable by any adult with an IQ>70. There are not so shitty scene releases that compress content using more efficnet systems than the original and have negligible loss in quality. Some discs contain content that's not part of the game, not used by the game, and can be removed/moved to another disc without affecting the game in any way. In reality there are only a handfull of games where this is a real problem.
Using an ODE should be less complicated than burning discs, and not much more expensive if at all. Anyone who didn't buy GDEMUs for all their DCs when they were <$40 is a zoomer bandwagoner and thus irrelevent.

Sometimes I'll boot up Mario 64 just to dick around in Bob-omb Battlefield for a bit with Mario's movement; I'll never do the same with Banjo.
I still think Banjo is great, but truthfully I do think that Mario 64 remaining more prevalent in the public's eye makes more sense, and not even from just a "Mario is a bigger name than Banjo" sort of thing. Part of it might also just be that people are realizing that the N64 isn't THAT great of a platform now that a lot of the internet's nostalgia these days is driven by early-mid Y2K stuff instead of mid-late 90s stuff but I don't think the public is really there yet.

I’m convinced of two things:

2. The developers really really didn’t want you to beat this game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9493708
>I think this might be the kicker if anything. Banjo doesn't really have anything in his arsenal that really gives a burst of speed or acts as a movement combo tool.
There's a post right before yours that talks about the main speedrunning technique for going fast. Rolls give banjo acceleration. You then jump mid roll to shoot a decent chunk further and to stop the slowdown from the roll. Speedrunners also have a technique to cycle between the two continuously. That, and there also triple jump tricks to stay in the air longer, where Banjo moves quicker than on the ground. The talon trot is actually not the best speed technique even though it looks like it. Also, people don't realize there are techniques used to climb and scale vertical platforms, which all involve precision jumping. The people who say there aren't any interesting alternative routes in the game or there aren't any platforming challenges should look into those.

>>9493708
>I do agree that N&B gets far, far too much shit from people simply because it wasn't a proper Threeie like people wanted
It's not that fans expected more of the same and got something totally different. Rare literally promised more of the same and we got something totally different. At the time, there was a forum where rare gave updates about the game directly to fans. There was an official trailer for Banjo Kazooie 3. For whatever reason the game was scrapped and Banjo was put in a totally different game and most fans hated what they were seeing as soon as they said the game was moving in a different direction. I'm pointing this out because there's a common notion now that N&B was a decent game but everybody looked down on it because it was experimental and the fans didn't want it to be, but few people mention that there was originally a more traditional BK3 announced that was scrapped and replaced by N&B, and that's why the fans hated it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Honestly? Jet Moto.
The track design does not compliment the sluggish bike physics, and the grapple mechanic has an inexplicable delay between activation and actually pulling you around a tight turn so it often tosses you into a wall half the time, and this does not go well with the crashing mechanic that knocks you off your bike on any slight contact with anything.
The rolling mechanic is also useless, and only serves to crash you if you dare keep turning in one direction for too long.
Doing stunts in mid-air doesn't give you anything worthwhile like an extra boost charge so it's pointless to do them, and half the ramps in the tracks have some kind of obstacles above them just to crash your face into them, because god forbid you want to catch some sick air.
The generic surf rock soundtrack is so aggressively annoying that it actually makes me want to kill somebody.
Pretty sure SingleTrach only got to make 2 more sequels of this shit because of their previous repertoire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SF's gameplay is fairly underrated. People see lack of dual analog controls and shoulder buttons being used for strafing and immediately feel some kind of dissonance but I can't state enough how much I enjoy the gameplay and how smooth everything in those 3 games feel.

Framerate is steady - not great but steady. Going into manual mode puts you in the headshot plane and all you need to do is sweep horizontally with the dpad, and the sensitivity is great and pulling off spectacular shots is very easy. If the enemy is crouching, then all you need to do is crouch yourself and that fixes the vertical side of aiming.

I also really love how every single weapon in the game is a guaranteed one-hit kill if you do a headshot. And that even shotguns are lethal and accurate at long range.
Auto-aim also has suprising amount of depth - your body direction affects the accuracy so your accuracy is the best when you are walking head-on towards the enemy and worse when you are strafing. Just the gameplay loop is very fun and every weapon sees equal amount of use .

SF1 has some annoying respawning issues but generally speaking all 3 games are top tier action games with some very memorable level design. I wish everyone gave these games a chance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Uncharted Waters 2: New Horizons, for SNES.
Six character paths each with their own story that intersect with the others during the same events, each encouraging different play styles. There's 100+ ports, at least as many villages to discover (each with a treasure to find after befriending locals), you can game the economy in your favor, set up profitable trade routes. You can get a letter of marque from your monarch (you can defect and join other nations if you want) to raid rival nation's trade fleets. The dueling mechanics are this weird little card game that makes sense if you play it a little bit.
You can take out a loan from your bank, you can commission the building of new ships, invest in ports to make them have better goods available and open up the construction of better ships. There's a ton of side characters you can fight, or hire, or take jobs to collect debts from, all sailing around on their own journeys while you do yours. You can buy a cat which counters rats occurring on your ship, same with limes which you use when an ocean voyage goes beyond 50 days and your crew gets scurvy. The wind and ocean currents matter, there is at least one doldrum near the bottom of South America. There's so much shit for a game made in '92, I finished the Joao playthrough and Catalina one recently, I've got to go back after a break to finish the other four entire playthroughs left.

this game could've been great, but instead it was painfully mediocre. being able to shoot energy orbs in Rayman 2 was one of the coolest parts, and then of course they go back to the stupid punch from R1 with this game, and the special powers they added in place were lame as fuck. would've been cool if there was a bunch of different ones like ice fist, fire fist etc. but there were only like 4 and they had barely any combat utility. by far the worst part though was the shoehorned references. they did a complete 180 with murphy and turned him from a whispering advisor into a blaringly obnoxious retard with a new york accent that screams star wars references ever 2 minutes. i felt like i had a green, flying, jewish kevin smith harassing me the entire game. completely destroyed the melancholy and subtlety of the first game's style. what the fuck were they thinking? this is to say nothing of the "radical" art design changes like rayman's frosted tips that just scream out of touch early 2000s edginess that nobody asked for. the minigames were ass too, and the boss fights were extremely jank. i liked some of the level designs and collecting the gems was fun, but the story, atmosphere, and nuances of R2 were absolutely pooped on. the definitive 6/10 game.

>>9483058
I think it's mostly the perception of what makes a "good" translation for many people. Phoenix Wright is loved and it practically was a Working Designs style when it started out because of its attempts to go "no this isn't Japan what are you talking about haha hey Maya sure loves to eat HAMBURGERS am I right". But overall anime and Japanese media has become big and ingrained enough that the Working Designs/4Kids/Saban levels of translating something is more met with derision than "oh boy anime". Even when Nintendo tossed memes into localized scripts of their games, people are more likely to groan and wish they weren't there now.

I think part of it too is that Working Designs translated Magic Knights Rayearth, which has the honor of being the last western Sega Saturn game. If it were anything else, sure, but Rayearth was an established franchise and WD putting on their trademark brand of humor soured a lot to them: even back when the game was new, people felt it was an awkward and out of place translation for the game because the anime was available and already had fans. So you have a game that hits a lot of "oh should I check this out" flags (last console release in the west, based on a beloved series, etc) and get hit with "eh, they made it worse" is sort of an "the Emperor isn't wearing any clothes" moment for them.

Also they put an ammo system into Silhouette Mirage and that personally rankled me because it meant you never wanted to experiment with different weapons due to the cost to use them, then they added grinding for money on top of it. They frequently mistook tedium for difficulty.

Sega Saturn Magazine: Dynamite Deka is called Die Hard Arcade in the West. Is the content the same?
Makoto Uchida: The versions are almost identical. The difference is that in Die Hard Arcade, the building is called the Nakatomi building, and you can see the Nakatomi symbol here and there. That’s been cut out of the Japanese version.
Sega Saturn Magazine: Are there differences between the characters in both versions?
Makoto Uchida: Yes, quite a lot. For Die Hard Arcade, 20th Century Fox told us to not stray from the story of Die Hard too much. Since the movie didn’t revolve around the president [of the U.S.] , we were told to make the girl appearing in the game into the daughter of the head of Nakatomi. The overall story was to be about terrorists taking over the Nakatomi building. The name of the male character (player one) was accordingly changed to John McClane, and the female player character (player two) also got a name that was different from the Japanese version. Content-wise, the games are almost the same, and even the story isn’t that different on the whole.

>Have you ever noticed that the Turbografx is actually just a black PC Engine with a big tumor attached to its left and rear sides?
Funny enough that redesign may have actually killed the console. NEC was targeting a Christmas 88 release but the sentiment that >>9483082 America needs a bigger device pushed them redesign the console, they took 7 months to design, prototype, produce and ship the new console, by the time they arrived for sale in summer of 89 the folks at Sega had already launched their Genesis system in America 2 weeks in advance and planned an aggressive ad campaign to claiming the TG16 was weak in comparison to the Genesis. Since PCe was already big in Japan and beating Sega there they pre-assumed victory and skimped on heavy marketing of the TG16 in favor of over production to meet a non-existent demand. That meant shelves full of unsold TG16's and people asking when the new Sega would be in stock... if they had the most powerful system on the market for 7 months, getting in peoples homes, spreading via word of mouth well, maybe the big rivalry of the 90's would be Nintendo vs NEC and not Sega.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9488036
FFC's requirements for RF shielding were written way before gaming consoles were even a concept and were originally intended for actual broadcasting equipment like radios. Since most gaming machines contained an RF modulator inside them, they had to obey to those specs. Before 1980s the specs were absolutely draconian and multiple 1970s consoles and computers had to be delayed for months because FCC thought that they didn't have enough metal around all electronics. These requirements were later greatly reduced, which in turn led to a many new machines being released in early 1980s. By the 1990s it was pretty much agreed that FCC's fears were based on outdated research.

>>9477808
177 for the NEC PC-8801 released in 1986 by dB-soft. Its title of the game is a reference to a Japanese legislation concerning underage rape.

The game has you take the role of a rapist chasing after a woman. If you can catch her and complete a minigame where you pleasure her she marries you, If you fail to catch her or fail the minigame you are arrested. It wasn't tbe first commercial PC release to depict rape as a gameplay concept but notable the Komeito Party of the Japanese Diet referenced the game specifically during a discussion of age ratings and the limits of what a video game should be able to depict.

well not super modern anymore, but probably about 30 years ago, based on the person and on his story. It was after the end of the cold war. Guy says he was with coworkers (all US military, but in plain clothes, and no obviously military haircuts), taking a trip around eastern germany, touring castles and such. Claims they went into a random beer hall for food and drink, and not long after they arrived, happened to be there for a surreal display, in which an old guy (called "grandpa" by the staff) came in, they revealed a bunch of previously covered images of Nazi symbols and a large portrait of Hitler, and played the Nazi period version of the national anthem while everybody stood at attention, with some singing along (the old guy saluting the portrait).

Coworker says he was really lucky that despite being American military, he 1) had German ethnicity and looked the part (and the others more or less passed for "European"), 2) he knew German well enough to pass as someone who might be from around the area, and 3) none of his non-german speaking compatriots had said anything to anyone and so had plausible deniability. Said they had been eating and drinking normally before that point, but upon seeing all that (and apparently spotting a number of knives and brass knuckles and other weapons at different tables) decided they should GTFO. Compatriots thanked him for picking a lunch place that all but could have gotten them killed.

Thinking about it again, my only conclusion is that it must have been a small pocket of extremist germans hiding out in this small town. Given the recent news out of Germany, it doesn't seem as wild as it did when I first heard it.

I know there was a terrorist cult simulator based on Aum Shinrikyo made for the PC-98.
And despite urban legends claiming that it was actually made by the cult, it's not.

Hong Kong '97 is also edgy, as it involves a guy committing genocide on the entire population of Mainland China, while images of real war victims (from the Bosnian War and the Holocaust) can be seen, and it also has an F-bomb, which was extremely rare for the Super NES/Super Famicom.

Halo itself was a great series but its influence on the industry was pretty disastrous. Mainly it standardized dual stick + aim assist aiming for consoles which is awful because its designed to trick console players into thinking its not there, and it just aims for them. At the time it was the only solution that could have worked but now that both Sony and Nintendo have controllers that support dual stick + gyro aim, thats the far better way to aim in console shooters, debatably on par with KBM, but aim assist will never go away because console players are far too accustomed to it.

Ask any PC gamer what they think of console FPS and most of them disapprove solely because of the aim assist control scheme - something that console only casuls will never notice. And superior aim methods that are now possible will never take off because Halo caused one thing to be too well established.

>>9490576
Actual poster, I'll elaborate. Hl1 was lightning in a bottle, it came at the perfect time and introduced innovate things to the FPS genre. It had some "magic", as bad as a decriptor that is. The weapons felt good, the movement was just right, etc. It got a bit boring near the end, but the rest was peak 90's gaming. HL2 on the other hand was just a pretty good FPS game. There's nothing WRONG with it exactly, but it's just not very special compared to contemporary games. I remember playing Doom3 at the time and I enjoyed that at least as much as HL2, and Doom3 is not a fantastic game by any means. Many weapons in HL2 feel off and sloppy (the pistol that goes "paff paff paff", the smg that just spits out bullets in a weird spray without any real recoil in between bullets but just a random cone of dispersion, etc). The characters and story feel forced, HL did not have a linear story you had to follow, the story was just a backdrop to the action. In HL2 you are forced to sit through what is essentially cutscenes with a lot of "who cares" characters that you are supposed to care about. It's also full of gimmicks, especially related to the physics.

If you're looking at majority of 6th generation consoles games that doesn't include Xbox, that may be true. But perfectly? You're too optimistic about that. We're just now getting chips with 2017 flagship mobile phone architectures. No android phone so far can run Rogue Squadron 2 on Dolphin at full speed on mobile outside of hacked iPhone 12s mostly due to CPU brute forcing. The Snapdragon 8 Gen 2 can probably do it but it is unreleased until 2023. You're looking until 2028 if the time lag is the same to get this power in a $150 device. For most of 6th generation, you're already pretty much there with the T618 and this is a chip that was already released in 2019 by Unisoc which is now just trickling down to this pricepoint. 6th generation is where mobile chips are going to feel like time stopped until someone is willing to eat a loss with a flagship mobile SOC on a device selling cheaply before the 2028 timeline when the chips become cheap enough.

Make sure you check the 'Sold' amount next to the listing. A reputable seller will typically have 50+ items sold for a decent one.

Also check and gauge the price range of typical items being sold do you make sure you're not getting ripped off. Aka for ex: do not pay $90 for a Miyoo Mini when it's supposed to be $40 to $60 etc on AliExpress if you track the item each week throughout the week.

I mention the whole price range thing because they can either overcharge you or have "a really good deal" which equivalates to a scam since the item will never ship or you'll get a PM stating "Dear friend (we don't have that item) etc"

I haven't had that happen to me yet but I've read some have had it happen here.

If you're ever unsure just copy and paste the link into this thread and ask for someone to vet it out to get a second opinion etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485101
Put JELOS onto the first SD card. Then when you feel like playing N64, take out the first SD card so it boots into Android and learn how to tweak MupenFZPro to run N64 games decently.

Make sure that when you're in Android mode to use the touch screen, swipe down, and apply the "CPU Boost" icon that's shaped like a processor since you're going to need the boost for emulation and it's not enabled by default so without it, it makes N64 appear sluggish.

Put some PC ports on it via Port Master. Compile Super Mario 64 PC port for the RG353V. Idk get creative, squeeze that machine to do everything and hoard ROM sets.

That all depends however if you got the Android capable one. If not, the Linux only one is gimped in comparison. And make sure you get a big SD card from a good brand like SanDisk or Samsung cause the default Chinese SD cards they give you are shit tier in the long run for reliability.

>>9492940
Speaking from experience, copying save data from older consoles like SNES etc is easy since you just have to find the corresponding .srm files and sync them over from a PC running an emulator to a handheld or phone's directory where saves are located

I've done this in RetroArch by forcing it to dump saves in a specific directory.

Your problem consists of a few workflow issues:
1. You need to find out if you can find a utility for a software modded PS3 to rip the save from an original PSP game. Pretty sure the saves are located on the device itself somewhere. You might even be able to use FTP between your Windows or Linux PC and the PS3 on your local LAN.

However I don't know if the save files are encrypted by default.

You might want to ask on the Batocera Linux Plebbit about this since I know it doesn't even involve Batocera but a lot of people who use that retro gaming Linux distro are into weird workflows like this

2. If you haven't hacked your PS3, you should. It's fairly easy, just find out what model it is and look on YouTube for guides on how to do it. I mention this because I hacked a PS3 last year and it is the easiest browser software hack on earth with no mod chip or soldering needed.

3. Find out whatever PSP emulator that's available on that handheld device and figure out how the saves work on it so you can plan your attack a bit easier.

I mention this because I had to transfer saves from a fucking actual Nintendo 3DS aka Pokemon saves by ripping it via a community tool, and then figuring out where RetroArch places the saves by default on Batocera Linux and also how Anbernic devices utilize saves.

It wasn't easy but I found out that you can basically ssh into these Anbernic handhelds so if you can ssh, you can also use 'sshfs' from your desktop computer to mount the Anbernic handhelds as file directories so you can dump ROMs or saves onto it. Along with using 'rsync -a' you can remotely manage these devices and sync saves across them.

Went to shows in the late 90s/early 2000s on east coast. Phillyclassic and Eastcoast gaming expos i think. Fun times, mostly focused on pre nes nostalgia at the time. If you needed a sign of the times from that era, i was in a tournament at one for Nintendo World Champs 1990 and if you won, you got the cart and also Ralph Baer was a guest at these.

Late 2000s was kind of a dead period, but there were these small, 1 room shows like in hotels i would go to that were fun. I kinda miss those small ones the most. Pretty sure thats how toomanygames started.

And as for the last decade or so, ive only been to Toomanygames and some show in new jersey. Also kinda prefer the non strictly gaming shows more then the game ones now because not as many people are trying to fuck you with prices. Would like to check out the ones in new york some day.

I really would like to try and set up a small convention some day, nothing huge, not all of gaming but maybe more like a meet up/swap meet for vintage computers or something. I have a local small convention center open that would seem like a good place to hold one.
